title: State v. Holmes
description: This death penalty case involves the issue of whether the trial court erred by refusing to admit evidence of third-party guilt.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Bobby Lee Holmes, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
  Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25886
  Heard February 19, 2004 - Filed November 1, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda Haile, of Columbia, for appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General 
          John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
          all of Columbia; and Thomas E. Pope, of York, for respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Appellant was convicted [1]  of murder, first degree burglary, first degree criminal sexual 
  conduct (CSC), and robbery.Â  He received a death sentence for the murder, the 
  jury having found three statutory aggravating circumstances, [2]  and received three concurrent sentences for the other offenses. 
  [3]  Appellant alleges errors occurred in both the guilt phase and the sentencing 
  phase of his trial.Â  We affirm appellantâ€™s convictions and sentences.
FACTS
At approximately 6:15 a.m. on December 31, 1989, the eighty-six-year-old victim 
  opened her door in response to someoneâ€™s knocking.Â  A black male forced his 
  way into her apartment, beat her about the chest and head, and demanded money.Â  
  The man forced the victim into her bedroom where he ripped off her nightgown 
  and anally raped her.Â  He took $40 from her purse and left the apartment after 
  ripping the living room phone from the wall.
At 7:45 a.m., the victimâ€™s friend (Mrs. Thrasher) phoned to check on the victim.Â  
  After six or seven rings, the victim answered and told Mrs. Thrasher she had 
  been beaten, anally raped, and robbed.Â  Mrs. Thrasher called another friend, 
  Mrs. Byers, who had an automobile and a key to the victimâ€™s apartment.Â  Mrs. 
  Byers went to the apartment, noticed it was messy, spoke with the victim who 
  told her the assailant was â€œbig and dark,â€ and then drove to the police department 
  since the living room phone had been pulled off the wall. 
  [4] 
The first officer on the scene was Dale Edwards.Â  The victim told him that 
  around 6 or 6:30 a.m. she heard knocking at her front door and that when she 
  opened the door, a black male forced his way in.Â  She had taken a shower before 
  the police arrived.Â  Officer Edwards removed the sheets and pillowcase from 
  the bed for use as evidence, and placed the items in a paper grocery bag taken 
  from the victimâ€™s kitchen.Â  Lt. Barnett arrived and assisted in the evidence 
  collection.Â  A pink nightgown, a housecoat, and a rag were removed from the 
  bathroom and placed in another grocery bag.Â  The victim gave Officer Edwards 
  a pink paper towel with blood on it that he placed in a manila envelope brought 
  to the scene by Captain Mobley, the third officer on the scene.
While the three police officers were there, two paramedics arrived to transport 
  the victim to a local hospital emergency room.Â  Blood samples were taken, but 
  a rape kit was not processed because the victim was complaining of hip pain 
  and medical personnel were awaiting X-rays before performing the exam.Â  The 
  blood testing kit used to take samples from the victim had â€œexpiredâ€ several 
  months earlier. [5] Â  Before the 
  victimâ€™s mental state began to deteriorate, she described her attacker to an 
  emergency room nurse as a black male in his late twenties.Â  On February 19, 
  1990, the victim was transferred to a nursing home where she died in March.Â  
  The cause of death was pneumonia, which developed as the consequence of her 
  severe brain injury.Â  
Captain Mobley testified he arrived at the victimâ€™s apartment as the EMS personnel 
  were transporting her out the door.Â  He took custody of the evidentiary items 
  from Officer Edwards and Lt. Barnett.Â  He sent Officer Edwards door to door 
  in the neighborhood and instructed Lt. Barnett to go to the hospital and speak 
  with the victim.
Lt. Barnett recorded the victimâ€™s statement at the 
  hospital emergency room before she became confused.Â  She described her attackerâ€™s 
  clothing: â€œa dark jacket, must have been blue or black, must have been black;â€ 
  â€œa pair of those funny looking pants . . . not the old pant, but something thatâ€™s 
  kind of mixed up you know;â€ his hair: â€œkind of long.Â  Not too long, but a little 
  longer than you usually wear it;â€ she then said: â€œhe was middle aged.Â  He was 
  young.Â  He was not too young.Â  And he, as I remember, his hair was not short 
  or not too long.â€Â  The victim described her attacker as dark skinned, â€œnot too 
  heavy.Â  Not too slim.â€Â  
Later that day, Officer Edwards talked to several of the victimâ€™s neighbors.Â  
  Ms. Boyd told him she heard knocking at her door about 3 a.m.; Mr. Lynn, who 
  lived next door to the victim, reported knocking between 5:30 a.m. and 6:30 
  a.m.; and Ms. Diggs, who lived on the other side of the victim, heard someone 
  knocking on her door around 6 or 6:30 a.m.
Officer Grady Harper testified he was dispatched to an apartment complex near 
  the victimâ€™s residence at about 4:43 a.m. on December 31, 1989.Â  A number of 
  people, including appellant, were making a disturbance, and Officer Harper told 
  them to quiet down and move on.Â Â Â  Appellant was unruly, and Officer Harper 
  called for back-up to assist in arresting appellant.Â  When the additional officers 
  arrived, appellant ran.Â  Officer Harper saw appellant get into a car; Officer 
  Harper gave chase in his patrol car.Â  The driver stopped the car and appellant 
  ran from it.Â  The last time Officer Harper saw appellant was about 5:30 a.m. 
  and the other officers were chasing appellant.Â  One of the â€œchasingâ€ officers 
  testified he lost sight of appellant at about 5:20 a.m.Â  Appellant was wearing 
  a black sweater with a hood and blue jeans. 
Captain Mobley testified that after Officer Edwards and Lt. Barnett left the 
  victimâ€™s apartment; he locked the front door and began processing the scene.Â  
  He seized one more paper towel, the telephone touched by the assailant, and 
  the victimâ€™s purse.Â  He then dusted the apartment for fingerprints.Â  On the 
  interior side of the front door he photographed and lifted a palm print located 
  slightly above the doorknob.Â  Captain Mobley also photographed and lifted a 
  print from the outside of the front door.Â  The inside palm print was later identified 
  as that of appellant.Â  
Â Appellant was arrested on the afternoon of December 
  31, 1989, at his fatherâ€™s home in York, and denied ever having been inside the 
  victimâ€™s apartment.Â  When the police arrived, appellant was wearing a black 
  hooded sweatshirt, underwear, and socks.Â  He dressed in jeans before being transported 
  by the police.Â  While he was dressing, Officer Boot Smith noticed a tank top 
  that appeared to have blood on it and asked if the police officers could take 
  it.Â  Appellant consented and stated the blood came from a fight he had been 
  involved in the night before at a bar. 
Forensic evidence linked appellant to the crime scene.Â  In addition to the 
  palm print found on the victimâ€™s door, the State introduced evidence that:

  (1) fibers consistent with a black sweatshirt owned by appellant were found 
    on the victimâ€™s bed sheets;
  (2) a blue acrylic fiber was found on the victimâ€™s pink nightgown, and another 
    on appellantâ€™s blue jeans:Â  they â€œcould have come from the same common source 
    or it could have come from different sources, but indeed they do . . . match 
    each other;â€ 
  (3) microscopically consistent fibers were found on the pink nightgown and, 
    in the form of a â€œfiber pill,â€ on appellantâ€™s underwear;
  (4) appellantâ€™s underwear contained a mixture of DNA from two individuals 
    and 99.99% of the population other than appellant and the victim were excluded 
    as contributors to that mixture; and
  (5) appellantâ€™s tank top was found to contain a mixture of his blood and 
    the victimâ€™s blood.Â  

The defense theory was two-fold.Â  
  First, it sought to discredit the forensic evidence by showing the evidence 
  was mishandled and by demonstrating the many opportunities for contamination 
  because of unprofessional errors.Â  The defense also sought to suggest that the 
  alleged contamination was not merely the result of simple negligence, but part 
  of a plot on the part of certain law enforcement officers to see that appellant 
  was convicted of these crimes.Â  In connection with this prong of the defense 
  strategy, appellant sought to introduce evidence of third party guilt.Â  
ISSUE

  Whether the circuit court erred by refusing to admit evidence of third party 
    guilt? Â 

DISCUSSION
At a pretrial hearing, appellant proffered evidence of third party guilt.Â  
  Specifically, he sought to introduce evidence at trial that the crimes were 
  actually committed by Jimmy McCaw White (Jimmy).
1. Pre-trial testimony
Like appellant, Jimmy is a black male.Â  At the time of the victimâ€™s murder, 
  he was twenty-two years old; appellant was eighteen.Â  Jimmyâ€™s hair was longer 
  than appellantâ€™s and Jimmy had lighter skin than appellant.
Several witnesses placed Jimmy in the victimâ€™s neighborhood near 6 a.m. on 
  December 31, 1989.Â  Frenetta Johnson testified she saw Jimmy going toward the 
  apartments where the victim lived between 4:30 and 5:30 a.m.Â  Later in her testimony, 
  she narrowed the time to â€œfrom four-thirty to something to five.â€Â  Meshelley 
  Gilmore testified she observed Jimmy in an apartment parking lot as she drove 
  away from her home at about 3:30 or 4 a.m., and that he was still there when 
  she returned at 4:30-4:45 a.m.Â  These apartments were near the victimâ€™s complex.Â  
  Mrs. Gilmore was awakened by a police officer knocking on her door at 7:30 a.m.Â  
  She told him she had seen Jimmy hanging around the parking lot earlier that 
  morning. 
Deloris Brown testified she saw Jimmy walking down the victimâ€™s street in the 
  direction of the victimâ€™s apartment between 4 and 5 a.m. on December 31, 1989.Â  
  Eighty-seven-year-old Anna Boyd, a resident of the same apartment complex as 
  the victim, testified that someone knocked on her door during the night of December 
  30-December 31.Â  The knocker said, â€œOpen the door, my man, this is Jimmy, open 
  the door.â€Â  These are appellantâ€™s â€œproximityâ€ witnesses.
Appellant also presented several witnesses who testified that Jimmy had acknowledged 
  that appellant was â€œinnocentâ€ or to whom Jimmy had admitted his guilt.Â  Thomas 
  Murray testified that Jimmy said he knew appellant was innocent, and that he 
  (Jimmy) could not be brought to court for it.Â  Ken Rhodes testified he asked 
  Jimmy whether the word on the street, that Jimmy was the victimâ€™s murderer, 
  was true and that Jimmy â€œput his head down and he raised his head back up and 
  he said well, you know, I like older women. . . . and he never called the ladyâ€™s 
  name but you know he say that he liked old women and that yeah he did what they 
  say he did and you know that somebody else was locked up for it.Â  And you know 
  itâ€™s like he didnâ€™t have no regrets about it at all.â€Â  Rhodes went on to testify 
  that â€œ[Jimmy] didnâ€™t say exactly what he done, he just told me that she had 
  some good stuff . . . He said that he didnâ€™t kill the lady.Â  The lady was alive 
  when he left . . . .â€
Mattie Mae Scott testified that in October 1997 she was at her sonâ€™s house 
  when Jimmy came to visit.Â  Jimmy was â€œpartially intoxicated,â€ and when the others 
  began talking about the â€˜old lady in Yorkâ€™ that Jimmy had raped and murdered, 
  Jimmy said, â€œYes, I did it but [appellant] is going to fry for it.â€ 
The defenseâ€™s â€œstar witnessâ€ was Stephen Westbrook. 
  [6] Â  He testified that in 1990 and again in 1994 Jimmy told him he had 
  broken into the victimâ€™s house and raped her.Â  Jimmy told Westbrook that Officer 
  Boot Smith [7]  had told Jimmy 
  to keep quiet about his guilt.Â  Westbrook further testified that Officer Smith 
  and Investigator Potts came to see Westbrook before appellantâ€™s first trial 
  and offered to get him out of jail if he would testify that appellant had confessed 
  to him.Â  Westbrook testified that in June 2000, about two months before this 
  pretrial hearing, he was brought to Rock Hill from Kirkland Correctional Institute.Â  
  In Rock Hill, he was confronted by several employees of the solicitorâ€™s office 
  who sought to convince him to testify against appellant in the upcoming second 
  trial.Â  Westbrook stated that the solicitorâ€™s office employees acknowledged 
  to him that they had manufactured underwear evidence incriminating appellant.Â  
  Westbrook also testified that Jimmy told him that Officer Smith was out to â€œframeâ€ 
  appellant, and that even appellantâ€™s former attorney had urged him to testify 
  against appellant.Â  Finally, Westbrook testified an employee of the solicitorâ€™s 
  office stated that, in addition to the manufactured underwear evidence, they 
  had lifted one of appellantâ€™s palm prints from the county jail door to use against 
  him at trial.Â  These are appellantâ€™s â€œconfessionâ€ witnesses.
Further, the defense called a witness who testified that when asked why he 
  would not confess, Jimmy told him â€œitâ€™s all over and done with and [appellant] 
  is going to do the time for it.â€ 
Â The former receptionist at the 
  York Public Defenderâ€™s Office testified that Jimmy brought up the crime in conversation 
  with her one day, and remarked that he did not believe appellant was guilty, 
  that maybe Jimmy knew who did it, and that everybody on the street knew.
Finally, the defense called Jimmy to testify at the pretrial hearing.Â  The 
  trial judge instructed Jimmy he had the right to remain silent and the 
  right to an attorney, and warned Jimmy that anything he chose to say 
  could be used against him.Â  Jimmy declined the offer of an attorney and opted 
  to testify.Â  Jimmy testified he left York and was home in Sharon by 2 a.m. on 
  December 31, 1989.Â  He claimed to have ridden with Junior Lytle.Â  Lytle, however, 
  testified at the pretrial hearing and denied driving Jimmy home to Sharon that 
  night.Â  Jimmy denied telling Stephen Westbrook that he had raped and killed 
  the victim and denied confessing in the presence of Thomas Murray or John Dixon 
  or telling the York Public Defenderâ€™s receptionist that he knew who killed the 
  victim.
2. 
  Standard for admitting third party guilt
We have held that a defendant seeking to present evidence 
  of third party guilt must meet this standard:

  [T]he evidence offered by accused as to the commission of the crime by another 
    person must be limited to such facts as are inconsistent with his own guilt, 
    and to such facts as raise a reasonable inference or presumption as to his 
    own innocence; evidence which can have (no) other effect than to cast a bare 
    suspicion upon another, or to raise a conjectural inference as to the commission 
    of the crime by another, is not admissible.

State v. Gregory, 198 S.C. 98, 104, 16 S.E.2d 532, 534 (1941) (citing 
  16 C.J. 560).
The Gregory court went on to cite from 20 Am. 
  Jur. 254:

  But before such testimony can be received, there must be such proof of connection 
    with it, such a train of facts or circumstances, as tends clearly to point 
    out such other person as the guilty party.Â  Remote acts, disconnected and 
    outside the crime itself, cannot be separately proved for such a purpose.Â  
    An orderly and unbiased judicial inquiry as to the guilt or innocence of a 
    defendant on trial does not contemplate that such defendant be permitted, 
    by way of defense, to indulge in conjectural inferences that some other person 
    might have committed the offense for which he is on trial, or by fanciful 
    analogy to say to the jury that someone other than he is more probably guilty.

Id., 198 S.C. at 104-105, 16 S.E.2d at 535.Â  Further, 
  in State v. Gay, 343 S.C. 543, 541 S.E.2d 541 (2001), we held that where 
  there is strong evidence of an appellantâ€™s guilt, especially where there is 
  strong forensic evidence, the proffered evidence about a third partyâ€™s alleged 
  guilt does not raise a reasonable inference as to the appellantâ€™s own innocence. 

Appellant fails to meet the standard set out in Gregory and Gay 
  due to the strong evidence of his guilt.Â  He simply cannot overcome the forensic 
  evidence against him to raise a reasonable inference of his own innocence.Â  
  This evidence included:Â  (1) appellantâ€™s palm print was found just above the 
  door knob on the interior side of the front door of the victimâ€™s house; (2) 
  fibers consistent with a black sweatshirt owned by appellant were found on the 
  victimâ€™s bed sheets; (3) matching blue fibers were found on the victimâ€™s pink 
  nightgown and on appellantâ€™s blue jeans; (4) microscopically consistent fibers 
  were found on the pink nightgown and on appellantâ€™s underwear; (5) appellantâ€™s 
  underwear contained a mixture of DNA from two individuals, and 99.99% of the 
  population other than appellant and the victim were excluded as contributors 
  to that mixture; and (6) appellantâ€™s tank top was found to contain a mixture 
  of appellantâ€™s blood and the victimâ€™s blood. 
  [8] 
Further, besides the forensic evidence, there was evidence that appellant matched 
  the description of the perpetrator given by the victim and there was evidence 
  that appellant was fleeing from police officers and was in the area of the victimâ€™s 
  house prior to the time she was attacked.
Regarding appellantâ€™s claim that he should have been allowed to present evidence 
  that Jimmy White may have been the perpetrator of the crimes, the State proffered 
  the testimony of a Federal Bureau of Investigations forensic examiner.Â  This 
  examiner testified that, after testing Jimmy Whiteâ€™s specimen, i.e. a 
  dried bloodstain, and comparing the specimen to the clothing items that were 
  tested as part of the investigation, White was excluded.
Given the overwhelming evidence of appellantâ€™s guilt, the circuit court did 
  not err by excluding the evidence of third party guilt.
CONCLUSION
Appellantâ€™s remaining issues are without merit and we dispose of them pursuant 
  to Rule 220(b), SCACR.Â  See Issue I:Â  State v. Council, 
  335 S.C. 1, 515 S.E.2d 508, cert. denied, 528 U.S. 1050 (1999) (whether 
  juror is qualified to serve on death penalty case is within discretion of trial 
  court and is not reviewable on appeal unless wholly unsupported by the evidence; 
  responses of challenged jurors must be examined in light of entire voir dire); 
  Issue IV:Â  State v. Johnson, 338 S.C. 114, 525 S.E.2d 519, cert. 
  denied, 531 U.S. 840 (2000) (appellate court will not disturb trial courtâ€™s 
  ruling concerning scope of cross-examination of a witness to test his or her 
  credibility absent manifest abuse of discretion); see also State v. 
  Beckham, 334 S.C. 302, 513 S.E.2d 606 (1999) (trial court erred by not admitting 
  impeachment evidence after officer denied he had investigated two suspects different 
  from the defendant; however, error found to be harmless); Issue VI:Â  
  State v. Humphries, 325 S.C. 28, 479 S.E.2d 52 (1996), cert. denied, 
  520 U.S. 1268 (1997) (contemporaneous objection required to preserve issue for 
  appellate review); Issues VII and VIII:Â  State v. Hughes, 336 
  S.C. 585, 521 S.E.2d 500 (1999), cert. denied, 529 U.S. 1025 (2000) (capital 
  defendant may present as mitigating evidence (1) any aspect of defendantâ€™s character 
  or record and (2) any circumstances of the crime that may serve as a basis for 
  a sentence less than death); State v. Southerland, 316 S.C. 377, 447 
  S.E.2d 862 (1994), cert. denied, 513 U.S. 1166 (1995) [9]  (residual doubts are not a mitigating factor 
  in sentencing); Issue IX:Â  Ohio v. Roberts, 448 U.S. 56 (1980), 
  overruled on other grounds by Crawford v. Washington, Â Â Â Â Â U.S. 
  Â Â Â Â , 124 S.Ct. 1354 (2004) (properly administered the business and public 
  records exceptions are among the safest against a Confrontation Clause challenge 
  of the hearsay exceptions); Rule 1006, SCRE (contents of voluminous records 
  may be presented in form of a summary provided underlying data are admissible 
  into evidence); State v. Whipple, 324 S.C. 43, 476 S.E.2d 683, cert. 
  denied, 519 U.S. 1045 (1996) (prison disciplinary records admissible under 
  Uniform Business Records as Evidence Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 19-5-510 (1985); 
  Issue XI:Â  Payne v. Tennessee, 501 U.S. 808 (1991) (victim impact 
  evidence is admissible in a capital sentencing proceeding); Neill v. Gibson, 
  278 F.3d 1044 (10th Cir. 2001), cert. denied, 537 U.S. 835 
  (2002) (no ex post facto violation in allowing victim impact evidence 
  when crime occurred in 1984); Issue XII:Â  State v. Humphries, 
  325 S.C. 28, 479 S.E.2d 52 (1996), cert. denied, 520 U.S. 1268 (1997) 
  (contemporaneous objection required to preserve issue for appellate review); 
  Issue XIII:Â  State v. Stroman, 281 S.C. 508, 316 S.E.2d 395 (1984) 
  (party cannot complain of error which his own conduct has induced); Issue 
  XV:Â  State v. Weik, 356 S.C. 76, 587 S.E.2d 683 (2002), cert. 
  denied, 539 U.S. 930 (2003) (issues cannot be raised for the first time 
  on appeal); State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 551 S.E.2d 240 
(2001) (admission of evidence is in trial courtâ€™s discretion and will not be 
  disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion). [10] 
Proportionality Review
Under State law, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C)(3) (1985) requires this Court 
  to determine in a death case â€œ[w]hether the sentence of death is excessive or 
  disproportionate to the penalty imposed in similar cases, considering both the 
  crime and the defendant.â€Â  There is no requirement the sentence be proportional 
  to any particular case; however, death sentences have been imposed in similar 
  cases. Â See State v. Simmons, Â Â Â Â Â S.C. Â Â Â Â , 599 
  S.E.2d 448 (2004); State v. Terry, 339 S.C. 352, 529 S.E.2d 274, cert. 
  denied, 531 U.S. 882 (2000); State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 515 S.E.2d 
  508, cert. denied, 528 U.S. 1050 (1999); State v. Whipple, 324 
  S.C. 43, 476 S.E.2d 683, cert denied, 519 U.S. 1045 (1996).Â  Accordingly, 
  appellantâ€™s sentence is not disproportionate under State law.Â  The judgment 
  of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED. 

TOAL, C.J., WALLER, J., and Acting Justice John W. Kittredge, concur.Â  PLEICONES, 
  J., dissenting in a separate opinion.

 
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent, and would find the circuit 
  court erred in refusing to allow appellant to introduce evidence of third party 
  guilt in the guilt phase of the trial.Â  I would therefore reverse and remand 
  for a new trial.
The majority and I agree on the third party guilt evidence proffered by appellant.Â  
  In my view, the proffer met the standard established by State v. Gregory, 
  198 S.C. 98, 16 S.E.2d 532 (1941).Â  The majority, relying on State v. Gay, 
  343 S.C. 543, 541 S.E.2d 541 (2001), concludes that the third party guilt evidence 
  was properly excluded.Â  I find Gay distinguishable.
In Gay, the Court affirmed the exclusion of evidence of third party 
  guilt because the Stateâ€™s case, particularly the forensic evidence, was so strong 
  that it admitted of no â€œreasonable inferenceâ€ regarding the defendantâ€™s innocence.Â  
  The present case is distinguishable from Gay in several important particulars.Â  
  First, the validity of the forensic evidence was not called into question in 
  Gay.Â  Here, appellant presented evidence of mishandling, for example 
  the collection of evidence at the scene using grocery bags from the victimâ€™s 
  kitchen, the mislabeling of samples at the lab, and the loss of all blood samples 
  collected from the victim.Â  Further, appellant proffered evidence that representatives 
  of the State had admitted manufacturing blood and palm print evidence against 
  him.Â  Finally, unlike the defendant in Gay, appellant proffered both 
  â€œproximityâ€ witnesses and â€œconfessionâ€ witnesses.Â  Considering the record as 
  a whole, the Stateâ€™s evidence was not sufficient to negate the â€œreasonable inferenceâ€ 
  of appellantâ€™s innocence arising from appellantâ€™s proffer.
I would reverse and remand for a new trial.


 
   [1] This 
    was appellantâ€™s second capital trial.Â  His direct appeal from the first trial 
    was affirmed, State v. Holmes, 320 S.C. 259, 464 S.E.2d 334 (1995), 
    cert. denied, 517 U.S. 1248 (1996); appellant was subsequently granted 
    a new trial on post-conviction relief.

 
   [2] The 
    aggravating circumstances were murder during the commission of burglary, murder 
    during the commission of CSC, and physical torture.

 
   [3] The 
    imprisonment terms were life for burglary; thirty years for CSC; and fifteen 
    years for robbery.

 
   [4] The 
    victim apparently answered Mrs. Thrasherâ€™s call using her bedroom phone.

 
   [5] Appellant 
    includes the use of an expired kit in his argument that the forensic evidence 
    was compromised.Â  There was evidence, however, that the expiration date is 
    a manufacturerâ€™s â€œguessâ€ as to how long the vacuum in the blood collection 
    vials will remain good, and that the kit can be used after that date if the 
    vacuum remains effective. 

 
   [6] Westbrookâ€™s 
    credibility was called into question by cross-examination and by impeachment.

 
   [7] Boot 
    Smith was deceased at the time of this trial.

 
   [8] Although 
    appellant claims the forensic evidence was mishandled and therefore was inadmissible, 
    the fact the forensic evidence may have been compromised by the unprofessional 
    manner in which the evidence was collected goes to the weight of the evidence, 
    not to its admissibility.Â  See State v. Carter, 344 S.C. 419, 
    544 S.E.2d 835 (2001) (weak links in chain of custody go to weight, not admissibility); 
    State v. Smith, 326 S.C. 39, 482 S.E.2d 777 (1997) (storage of blood 
    sample in police officerâ€™s home goes to weight of evidence not its admissibility).Â  
    In any event, appellantâ€™s claims do not eviscerate all of the forensic evidence.Â  
    For example, appellantâ€™s claims do not eliminate the fact that consistent 
    fibers were found on both his clothing and the victimâ€™s clothing and sheets 
    or the fact that 99.99% of the population other than appellant and the victim 
    were excluded as contributors to the mixture found in appellantâ€™s underwear.

 
   [9] Overruled 
    on other grounds by State v. Chapman, 317 S.C. 302, 454 S.E.2d 
    317 (1995).

 
   [10] As 
    for Issue XIV, appellantâ€™s argument is based upon a factual error.Â  Appellant 
    argues the trial court erred by permitting the State to cross-examine a social 
    worker using records from his stay in Gilliam Psychiatric Hospital in 2000.Â  
    However, the trial court in fact denied the Stateâ€™s request to cross-examine 
    the social worker and the State did not ask any questions regarding the 2000 
    Gilliam records.Â  Because the Record on Appeal does not support appellantâ€™s 
    assertion, we do not address his argument.Â  See State v. Sinclair, 
    275 S.C. 608, 274 S.E.2d 411 (1981) (where appellant obtained only relief 
    he sought, this court has no issue to decide).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
       
        Gary R. Slezak, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        South Carolina Department of Corrections, Respondent. 
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
  Â Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25887
  Heard October 7, 2003 - Filed November 1, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED AND REMANDED IN PART

 
   
     
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        David M. Tatarsky, Mary Davenport Anderson, and Kelli Gregg Maddox, 
          all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal from two circuit court orders 
  upholding an administrative law judgeâ€™s (ALJâ€™s) determination that he lacked 
  jurisdiction over six grievances filed by inmate Gary Slezak (appellant).Â  We 
  affirm as to one grievance, affirm as modified as to four, and reverse and remand 
  one for reconsideration in light of our decision in Sullivan v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Corrections, 355 S.C. 437, 586 S.E.2d 124 (2003).Â  Further, we 
  clarify the jurisdiction of the Administrative Law Judge Division (ALJD) in 
  inmate grievance matters.
In Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 527 S.E.2d 742 (2000), the Court 
  held that inmates could pursue appellate review in the ALJD of certain grievance 
  decisions made by the Department of Corrections (DOC).Â  The ALJD responded to 
  Al-Shabazz in an en banc order issued September 5, 2001.Â  McNeil 
  v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections.Â  In McNeil, the ALJD purported 
  to limit its appellate jurisdiction in inmate appeals to grievances where:

   1)     the contention is that the inmateâ€™s sentence, 
    sentence-related credits or custody status have been erroneously calculated, 
    or
   2)     the inmateâ€™s created liberty interest has been 
    taken as punishment in a major disciplinary hearing.

In footnote 5 of Sullivan, this Court substantially modified McNeil 
  and held:

  â€¦.the ALJD and the circuit court are instructed to look to this opinion, 
    not McNeil, for guidance in future cases.Â  Although much of McNeilâ€™s 
    analysis is accurate, we believe Wolff [v. McDonnell, 418 U.S. 
    539 (1974)] requires minimal due process when for [sic] state-created liberty 
    interests, which are not necessarily limited to sentence credit issues and 
    major disciplinary decisions.

See also Wicker v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, Op. No. 
  25859 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed August 23, 2004) (recognizing another limited ALJD 
  jurisdictional exception where inmate claims deprivation of property interest).
We now clarify that the ALJD has subject matter jurisdiction to hear appeals 
  from the final decision of the DOC in a non-collateral or administrative matter.Â  
  Al-Shabazz, supra.Â Â Â  Subject matter jurisdiction refers to the 
  ALJDâ€™s â€œpower to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the 
  proceedings in question belong.â€Â  Cf. Dove v. Gold Kist, Inc., 
  314 S.C. 235, 442 S.E.2d 598 (1994) (definition of judicial subject matter jurisdiction).Â  
  Further, the ALJD has appellate jurisdiction over any matter where the procedural 
  prerequisites for perfecting such an appeal have been met.Â  Great Games, 
  Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Rev., 339 S.C. 79, 529 S.E.2d 6 (2000) (appellate 
  jurisdiction exists where procedural requirements met).
While the ALJD has jurisdiction over all inmate grievance appeals that have 
  been properly filed, we emphasize that the Division is not required to hold 
  a hearing in every matter.Â  Summary dismissal may be appropriate where the inmateâ€™s 
  grievance does not implicate a state-created liberty or property interest.Â  
  See Sandin v. Conner, 515 U.S. 472 (1995) (due process clause 
  offended only when inmate subjected to atypical and significant hardships in 
  relation to ordinary incidents of prison life).
Appellantâ€™s appeals to the ALJD and to the circuit court were decided prior 
  to our opinions in Sullivan and Wicker, and were dismissed as 
  beyond the ALJDâ€™s jurisdiction pursuant to the McNeil order.Â  In the 
  interest of judicial economy, we will address this appeal on its merits.
ISSUE

  Whether the circuit court erred in dismissing appellantâ€™s grievances?

ANALYSIS
We address each of appellantâ€™s six grievances below.
Appellant first complained that 
  DOC seized certain educational cassette tapes in appellantâ€™s possession.Â  The 
  record reveals that the DOC policy denies inmates possession of cassette tapes 
  other than tapes of the inmateâ€™s parole hearing(s) or religious tapes obtained 
  from the chaplain.Â  We find no protected liberty or property interest implicated 
  in the DOCâ€™s decision to declare cassette tapes contraband, and to seize appellantâ€™s 
  tapes pursuant to this policy.
Appellant also complains about 
  a DOC policy that provides for the loss of â€œgood timeâ€ credits in certain circumstances.Â  
  The record establishes that appellant is not eligible to receive such credits, 
  and accordingly lacks standing to challenge the DOC policy.
Appellantâ€™s third complaint relates 
  to a DOC policy limiting the amount of legal material he could keep in his cell 
  while in administrative segregation.Â  The DOC determined that the retention 
  of large amounts of paper in these cells created a fire hazard, and therefore 
  permitted an inmate to retain a limited amount in his cell with the remainder 
  available upon request.Â  Appellant concedes his materials were returned upon 
  his release from administrative segregation to the general population.Â  We find 
  this grievance is moot, and that, in any case, the decision to limit papers 
  for fire safety reasons does not implicate a protected liberty or property interest.
Appellant also complained because 
  DOC confiscated a book sent to him through the mail.Â  Under DOC policy, inmates 
  may receive only books mailed to them directly from the publisher for security 
  reasons.Â  Appellantâ€™s grievance does not involve a state-created liberty or 
  property interest.
Appellant also challenged S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-2-620 (Supp. 2004), which requires 
  inmates convicted of certain crimes to submit a DNA sample, and Â§ 23-3-670, 
  requiring the person providing the DNA sample to pay a $250 processing fee.Â  
  Appellantâ€™s counsel acknowledged at oral argument that appellant was challenging 
  the constitutionality of these statutes, and that such a challenge was properly 
  brought as a declaratory judgment action in circuit court rather than through 
  the administrative grievance process.Â  See e.g. Great Games, supra; 
  Video Gaming Consultants, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Rev., 342 S.C. 
  34, 535 S.E.2d 642 (2000).Â  This grievance was properly dismissed for lack of 
  jurisdiction. [1]  
Appellantâ€™s sixth grievance asserted that the practice of â€œtriple cellingâ€ 
  at McCormick Correctional Institute constituted both a security hazard and a 
  health hazard to inmates.Â  We find this grievance adequately states a violation 
  of appellantâ€™s liberty interest so as to entitle him to a hearing before an 
  ALJ.Â  Accordingly, we remand this grievance appeal to the ALJD for further proceedings.
CONCLUSION
We hold that the ALJD has jurisdiction 
  over all properly perfected inmate appeals, but clarify that it may summarily 
  decide those appeals that do not implicate an inmateâ€™s state-created liberty 
  or property interest.Â  We affirm as modified the orders upholding the dismissal 
  of five of appellantâ€™s complaints, and reverse and remand the triple celling 
  complaint to the ALJD.
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED AND REMANDED IN PART.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Doyet A. 
  Early, III, concur.


 
   [1]  Our disposition of this grievance is without prejudice 
    to appellantâ€™s right to pursue a declaratory judgment action in circuit court.

  IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court
  
  
    
      
        
          In the Matter of Paul W. Nevill,Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  Opinion No. 25888
  Submitted October 11, 2004 - Filed November 8, 2004
  
  PUBLIC REPRIMAND
  
  
    
      
        
          Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Senior Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
          Paul W. Nevill, of Bluffton, pro se.
        
      
    
  
  
  PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and agrees to either an admonition, public reprimand, or definite suspension not to exceed thirty (30) days.Â  We accept the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
  FACTS
  On December 31, 2003, respondent represented Purchaser in a real estate closing.Â  In that transaction, Purchaser was buying investment property from Seller for $240,445.00.Â  Seller was to manage the property for Purchaser.Â  
  Without consulting respondent, Purchaser paid $44,000.00 of her own money to Seller.Â  This payment was not required by the sales contract and was in addition to the $1,000.00 earnest money Purchaser was required to pay under the contract.Â  Purchaserâ€™s understanding was that these funds would be used to pay the balance owed on the purchase of the new property after the loan proceeds ($158,000) and the proceeds of the sale of other investment property owned by Purchaser ($61,014.17).Â  Any excess would be placed in Purchaserâ€™s property management account held by Seller.Â  Purchaser and Seller did not document the payment of the $44,000.00 or the terms of their agreement about its purpose.
  In preparation of the HUD-1 settlement statement, respondent correctly calculated that $27,948.08 of the $44,000.00 would be required for Purchaser to meet the sale price.Â  Respondent should have listed this amount on the â€œSummary of Borrowerâ€™s Transactionâ€ on the HUD-1 as a down payment paid outside of closing (POC).Â  Respondent should have then listed the same amount as an excess deposit POC on the â€œSummary of Sellerâ€™s Transactionâ€ on the HUD-1 and reduced the final amount to Seller by that amount.Â  Instead, respondent added the $27,948.08 to the $1,000 earnest money deposit on line 201 of the HUD-1 and showed that money being paid to Seller at closing.Â  
  Neither Purchaser nor Seller brought $27,948.08 to the closing.Â  Respondent conducted the closing without correcting the HUD-1.Â  As a result, respondent issued a trust account check to Seller for $27,948.08 more than respondent received to fund the closing.Â  
  On January 21, 2004, respondent realized the error when his bank contacted him and informed him there were insufficient funds in his trust account to cover a check issued in a subsequent closing.Â  Respondent immediately transferred $10,000.00 from his personal home equity account into his trust account to cover the check.Â  Upon review of his trust account records, respondent discovered that the error in the December 31, 2003 closing was the source of the shortage.Â  Respondent deposited the remaining amount available from his personal home equity account ($6,000.00) into his trust account, leaving the trust account $11,948.08 short. 
  Over the next several months, respondent did not withdraw funds owed to him for fees for subsequent closings in an effort to make up the shortage.Â  Respondent relied on the â€œfloatâ€ from those closings to avoid any losses to clients or returned checks.
  Respondent was able to make up the shortage in full by June 2004.Â  In discussion with the Sellerâ€™s attorney about repayment to respondent for the overpaid funds, it came to respondentâ€™s attention that use of the â€œfloatâ€ in his trust account was in violation of the Rules of Professional Conduct.
  Respondent self-reported this matter to the Commission on Lawyer Conduct.Â  He provided Disciplinary Counsel with complete records of the transactions and has fully cooperated in the disciplinary investigation.Â  
  LAW
  Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  Respondent admits that by his misconduct he has violated the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR, particularly Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall safe keep client property).Â  
  CONCLUSION
  We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
  PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
  TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court
  
  
    
      
        
          In the Matter of Michael V. Hart, Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  Opinion No.Â  25889
  Submitted October 8, 2004 - Filed November 8, 2004
  
  PUBLIC REPRIMAND
  
  
    
      
        
          Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Senior Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
          Desa A. Ballard, of West Columbia, for respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and agrees to either an admonition or a public reprimand.Â  We accept the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
  FACTS[1]
  Matter I
  Respondent was admitted to practice law in 1988.Â  Until approximately March 2003, respondent worked for several law firms, primarily representing plaintiffs or claimants.Â  From March 2003 through April 2004, respondent operated a solo practice in which he handled personal injury cases on a contingency fee basis.Â  
  In connection with his solo practice, respondent failed to maintain accurate or complete client ledgers, a check register or accounting journal, monthly account reconciliations, or any other system to facilitate the reliable identification of clients who had funds in his accounts and the balance of those funds.Â  During that same period, respondent failed to maintain copies or originals of checks written on his operating or trust account.Â  Respondent relied primarily on check stubs, on-line banking, and his own recollection to monitor the flow of funds through his accounts.Â  As a result, respondent was unable to identify client funds remaining in accounts at any given point in time.Â  
   It was respondentâ€™s practice to deposit a client settlement check into his trust account, confirm that the check had cleared, and then electronically transfer the funds from the trust account to his operating account.Â  Respondent then disbursed funds to and on behalf of clients from the operating account.Â  This practice was based on respondentâ€™s erroneous belief that his former employer, a more experienced attorney, processed settlements in this matter.Â  
  Respondent left a portion of his fees from client settlements in his trust account as a cushion.Â  Respondentâ€™s remaining fees from settlement funds often remained in his operating account for his use in connection with operating his law office and for his personal use.Â  Respondent failed to maintain records to ensure an accurate accounting of his accumulated fees in the trust account and the operating account.Â  Although no client or client creditor has complained that payment was not received, respondent acknowledges that he should have processed client settlements using only his trust account and that his deposit of client funds and earned fees into his operating account constituted commingling.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  Respondent prepared and negotiated eight operating account checks payable to cash.Â  Additionally, respondent used a debit or cash card to pay office expenses, to purchase personal items, and to make cash withdrawals from the operating account.Â  Respondent acknowledges that, because it contained client funds, his operating account was a de facto trust account and that it was improper to make disbursements from that account in cash.Â  Respondentâ€™s cash transactions and payments for office expenses and personal items were made from what respondent believed to be earned fees remaining in his operating account.Â  Although there is no indication respondent misappropriated client funds, he acknowledges that his lack of proper accounting and documentation raised a question of misappropriation and impaired his ability to confirm the integrity of client funds.
  On at least six occasions, respondent negotiated client settlement checks for cash without depositing them into his trust account.Â  Respondent failed to accurately and completely account for remittances of cash to these clients and to himself.Â  Although respondent did this as an accommodation to his clients and no client has complained of not receiving funds due, respondent acknowledges that it was inappropriate to make these disbursements in cash and to handle these settlements outside his trust account. 
  In addition to reporting this matter to the Commission on Lawyer Conduct, respondent retained an accountant with experience in law firm accounting.Â  Respondentâ€™s accounts have now been reconciled and all client funds have been accounted for and properly disbursed.Â  Respondent represents he now has in place accounting and recordkeeping practices that are fully compliant with the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR, and Rule 417, SCACR.Â  
  Matter II
  Of the approximately one hundred client files opened by respondent from March 2003 to April 2004, approximately seventy were referrals from other attorneys.Â  These files were referred to respondent for the purpose of litigation and/or final settlement.Â  Respondentâ€™s general agreement with the referring attorneys was to split any fees recovered on a fifty-fifty basis.Â  Respondent acknowledges that this fee-splitting arrangement was not necessarily in proportion to the amount of work performed by each attorney and, therefore, a written agreement with the client in which both attorneys acknowledged full responsibility for the matter was required.Â  Although the clients did consent to the referrals and no client has complained about the fee sharing arrangement, respondent and his referring attorney did not enter into the required written agreements with the clients regarding each attorneyâ€™s responsibility for the matters in violation of Rule 1.5 of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR.Â  
  LAW
  Respondent admits that by his misconduct he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.5 (division of fees between lawyers who are not in the same firm may be made only if the division is made in proportion to the services performed by each attorney or, by written agreement with the client, each lawyer assumes joint responsibility for the representation) and Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall hold property of clients in his possession separately from the lawyerâ€™s own property).Â  In addition, respondent agrees he has violated Rule 417, SCACR.Â  Respondent acknowledges his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  
  CONCLUSION
    
  
  We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
  PUBLIC REPRIMAND.Â Â Â  
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.


  [1] Both matters were initiated by respondentâ€™s self-report.Â

  IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court
  
  
    
      
        
          In the Matter of Verdell Barr, Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  Opinion No. 25890
  Submitted October 11, 2004 - Filed November 8, 2004
  
  PUBLIC REPRIMAND
  
  
    
      
        
          Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Senior Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
          Verdell Barr, of Kingstree, pro se.
        
      
    
  
  
  PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and agrees to either an admonition or a public reprimand.Â  We accept the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
  FACTS
  
  Matter I
  On April 26, 2001, respondent was appointed to represent Client A in a post-conviction relief action.Â  At the time of his appointment, respondent and his law partner had agreed that respondent would handle appointments in domestic cases and his partner would handle appointments in post-conviction relief cases.Â  Respondent referred the appointment of Client A to his law partner without notifying Client A or opposing counsel and without seeking substitution of counsel from the court.Â  
  Respondentâ€™s partner mistakenly believed Client A was no longer incarcerated because he saw someone matching Client Aâ€™s description in town.Â  The partner erroneously assumed Client A was no longer in need of post-conviction relief.Â  In fact, Client A remained incarcerated.
  From the date of respondentâ€™s appointment in April 2001 until January 2002, no action was taken on behalf of Client A.Â  On January 2, 2002, respondentâ€™s partner wrote the Office of the Attorney General inquiring about the status of the matter.Â  On March 11, 2002, Client A wrote respondent asking for contact from him and seeking information about his case.Â  Neither respondent nor his partner took further action.Â  
  On April 18, 2002, respondent was notified by Disciplinary Counsel that Client A had filed a grievance against him.Â  Respondent was given fifteen days to respond to the allegations.Â  After no response was received, Disciplinary Counsel sent a second letter on May 7, 2002, pursuant to In the Matter of Treacy, 277 S.C. 514, 290 S.E.2d 240 (1982), again requesting a response.Â  On May 16, 2002, respondent replied that his partner had agreed to handle the matter and that Client A had been seen in public.Â  He sent a copy of his response to Client A. 
  On May 24, 2002, Client A wrote respondent confirming he was still incarcerated.Â  In that letter, Client A requested information about his case and documents from his file.Â  
  On June 17, 2002, respondentâ€™s partner wrote Client A and asked for his consent for substitution of counsel.Â  Client A confirmed his consent to this arrangement.Â  No request for substitution of counsel was filed with the court.Â  
  On August 6, 2002, respondent resumed his representation of Client A.Â  He represented him at his hearing and filed a notice of appeal after his post-conviction relief application was denied.Â  Respondent subsequently referred the appeal to the Office of Appellate Defense which is now responsible for the representation.Â  
  Matter II
  Respondent was retained to represent Client B in connection with a dispute over the purchase of a vehicle.Â  Respondent filed a lawsuit on Client Bâ€™s behalf and ultimately negotiated a favorable settlement.Â  The settlement was entered on the record before the presiding judge in February 2001.Â  Respondent prepared a consent order, however, Client B subsequently requested modifications to the terms of the settlement agreement.Â  Respondent consulted with the judge.Â  The judge was unwilling to change the terms of the settlement.Â  Client B then refused to sign the consent order or pay respondentâ€™s outstanding fees and costs.Â  
  Client B alleged respondent had a conflict of interest, claiming respondent had a personal and professional relationship with the opposing party which he had not disclosed.Â  Investigation revealed no evidence of a conflict of interest nor any evidence that respondent provided anything but competent and diligent representation to Client B.Â  
  However, upon termination of representation, respondent failed to promptly comply with requests from Client B and Client Bâ€™s new counsel for the client file.Â  Client Bâ€™s telephone bills show twenty-three telephone calls to respondentâ€™s office from May 2002 to January 2002.Â  Client B also sent two certified letters, delivered to respondent on March 19, 2002 and June 24, 2002.Â  It was not until January 2004 that respondent sent the file to Client Bâ€™s new attorney.Â  
  Respondent failed to timely respond to Disciplinary Counselâ€™s inquiries in this matter.Â  
  LAW
  Respondent admits that by his misconduct he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to a client); Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep client reasonably informed about status of a matter and promptly comply with reasonable requests for information); Rule 1.16 (upon termination of representation, lawyer shall take steps to extent reasonably practicable to protect a clientâ€™s interests, such as surrendering papers to which client is entitled); Rule 3.2 (lawyer shall make reasonable efforts to expedite litigation consistent with interests of the client); Rule 8.1(b) (lawyer shall not fail to respond to lawful demand for information from disciplinary authority); and Rule 8.4(a) (it is processional misconduct for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct) and 7(a)(3) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to knowingly fail to respond to a lawful demand from a disciplinary authority).Â Â Â Â Â  
  CONCLUSION
  We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
  PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
  TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

  Submitted October 8, 2004 - Filed November 8, 2004
  
  DEFINITE SUSPENSION 
  
  
    
      
        
          Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Michael J. Virzi, Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
          Robert Lee Newton, Jr., of Pickens, pro se.
        
      
    
  
  
  PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to a definite suspension from the practice of law of up to one year, retroactive to the date of his interim suspension.Â  We accept the agreement and impose a one year suspension.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
  FACTS
  Between September 5, 2003, and September 18, 2003, law enforcement observed respondent cultivating marijuana plants in the woods behind his home.Â  On September 18, 2003, respondent was arrested by members of the Pickens County Sheriffâ€™s Department and charged with one count of manufacturing marijuana and one count of possession with intent to distribute (PWID) marijuana, both in violation of South Carolina Code Ann.Â  Â§ 44-53-370(b)(2) (1985).Â  At the time of his arrest, respondent was in possession of approximately 3.5 ounces of marijuana.Â  Based on the arrest warrants and affidavits contained therein, respondent consented to and was placed on interim suspension by order of the Court dated September 25, 2003.Â  
  Because respondent had previously worked as a prosecutor in Pickens County, his criminal prosecution was assigned to a solicitor in another circuit.Â  At all times relevant hereto, respondent has been fully cooperative with the solicitor assigned to his case and with Disciplinary Counsel, but has maintained his innocence on the PWID charge and stated the marijuana was solely for his personal use.Â  ODC is informed and believes that the solicitor assigned to respondentâ€™s criminal prosecution discovered no evidence consistent with an intent on respondentâ€™s behalf to distribute the marijuana.Â  On December 29, 2003, the PWID charge was dismissed as duplicative and unsupported by the available evidence; the PWID records were expunged by order dated May 28, 2004.
  Respondent voluntarily entered into drug counseling.Â  He was subsequently admitted to Pre-Trial Intervention (PTI) on March 8, 2004 in lieu of prosecution on the charge of manufacturing.Â  Respondent successfully completed PTI on June 10, 2004, the manufacturing charge was dismissed on June 14, 2004, and the records expunged by order dated June 16, 2004.Â  After investigation, Disciplinary Counsel also discovered no evidence consistent with an intent on respondentâ€™s part to distribute the marijuana.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
  LAW
  Respondent admits that by his conduct he has violated Rule 8.4(b) of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR.Â  Rule 8.4(b) provides it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to commit a criminal act that reflects adversely on the lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness, or fitness as a lawyer in other respects.Â  In addition, respondent admits that his actions constitute grounds for discipline under the following provisions of Rule 7, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR:Â  Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct) and Rule 7(a)(5) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal profession into disrepute).
  CONCLUSION
  We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and suspend respondent from the practice of law for one year retroactive to the date of his interim suspension.Â  Within fifteen days of the filing of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit demonstrating he has complied with the requirements of Rule 30 of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR.
  DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
  TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

  THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court
  
  
    
      
        
          The State, Petitioner,
        
      
    
  
  v.
  
    
      
        
          Eddie Lee Arnold, Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO 
  THE COURT OF APPEALS
  
  Appeal from Colleton County
  Donald B. Beatty, Circuit Court Judge
  
  Opinion No. 25892
  Heard January 6, 2004 - Filed November 8, 2004
  
  AFFIRMED
  
  
    
      
        
          Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, of Columbia; and Solicitor Randolph Murdaugh, III, of Hampton, for petitioner.
          Scott M. Merrifield and J. Brent Kiker, both of Kiker & Douds, P.A., of Beaufort; and Samuel C. Bauer, of Hilton Head Island, for respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Respondent Eddie Lee Arnold was convicted of murdering Dr. Jennings Cox of Savannah, Georgia. The State appeals the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision[1] reversing the denial of a directed verdict of acquittal.Â  We affirm. 
  FACTS
  Dr. Cox was missing for three days when his body was found off a dirt road near I-95 in Colleton County on June 21, 1997.Â  He had been shot twice, once in the head and once in the chest.Â  Although both bullets exited the victimâ€™s body, no projectiles or human tissue were found at the scene, nor was there any blood spattering or evidence of a struggle.Â  The victim had no wallet or identification but he was still wearing a watch and gold ring.Â  
  The last day Dr. Cox was seen alive was June 18. Â He went to his office in Savannah that morning where he saw patients as a child psychologist.Â  Because his car was being repaired, his wife drove him to work.Â  Between 10:30 and 11:00 a.m., Dr. Cox borrowed a colleagueâ€™s car to go to a dentist appointment.Â  The car was a nearly-new BMW Z3 two-seater, a car Dr. Cox had never borrowed before.Â  
  Dr. Cox never returned to the office.Â  At about 1:20 p.m., he called his secretary and she cancelled his remaining appointments.Â  Dr. Cox withdrew money from an ATM at a Hardeeville bank that day.[2]Â  His wife paged him every half-hour from about 2:30 until 5:30 p.m. without success.Â  She then filed a missing persons report.Â  
  Shortly thereafter, Dr. Coxâ€™s office manager discovered a floppy disk marked â€œpersonalâ€ lying on Dr. Coxâ€™s computer.Â  After viewing the data contained on the disk, she contacted police.Â  The information on the disk included the name of Bobby Ray Ware who was subsequently interviewed by police.
  Ware was the Stateâ€™s chief witness at trial.Â  He testified he was employed as a long-distance truck driver and lived in Savannah.Â  He had had a sexual relationship with Dr. Cox for more than a year but knew him only by the name â€œJay.â€Â  They first met at a rest area on I-95 when â€œJayâ€ performed oral sex on him.Â  After that, â€œJayâ€ would come to Wareâ€™s house about once a week for sex.Â  Because Ware knew â€œJayâ€ liked to have sex with truckers, on the weekend of June 14-15 he introduced â€œJayâ€ to respondent who was staying with Ware.Â  That weekend, â€œJayâ€ and respondent had sex at Wareâ€™s house.Â  Ware also testified he had seen respondent in possession of a gun while respondent was staying with him. 
  Ware left at 6:00 a.m. the following Tuesday, June 17, to drive to Chicago.Â  Respondent was still staying at Wareâ€™s residence.Â  On June 19, Ware received a message from respondent to call him at a phone number in Tennessee.Â  Ware later contacted respondent at a phone number identified as belonging to respondentâ€™s father who lived in Gray, Tennessee.Â  
  Meanwhile, on June 20, the borrowed BMW was found in a parking lot in Johnson City, Tennessee.Â  There was no blood in the car.Â  When recovered, it had some unspecified scratches on it.Â  The only evidence found in the car was a fingerprint on a tab from a coffee cup lid found in the center compartment between the seats.Â  The fingerprint was identified as respondentâ€™s right thumbprint.Â  
  Respondent was arrested at his fatherâ€™s house in Tennessee on June 27.Â  The Stateâ€™s theory of the case was that respondent and Dr. Cox drove to the woods where respondent shot Dr. Cox while Dr. Cox was kneeling â€œeither by force or for sex.â€Â  Respondent then drove the car to Tennessee and stopped for coffee on the way.Â  
  ISSUE
  
    Was there any substantial evidence to submit the case to the jury?
  
  DISCUSSION
  The Court of Appeals majority found there was no substantial evidence to submit the case to the jury and a directed verdict of acquittal should have been granted.Â  
  The trial court has a duty to submit the case to the jury where the evidence is circumstantial if there is substantial circumstantial evidence which reasonably tends to prove the guilt of the accused or from which his guilt may be fairly and logically deduced.Â  State v. Martin, 340 S.C. 597, 533 S.E.2d 572 (2000); State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 327, 468 S.E.2d 626 (1996).Â  Unless there is a total failure of competent evidence as to the charges alleged, refusal by the trial judge to direct a verdict of acquittal is not error. Â State v. Irvin, 270 S.C. 539, 243 S.E.2d 195 (1978).Â  The trial judge should grant a directed verdict, however, when the evidence merely raises a suspicion that the accused is guilty.Â  State v. Martin, supra. Â On appeal of the denial of a directed verdict of acquittal, we must look at the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Martin, supra; State v. Williams, supra. 
  Viewing the evidence most favorably to the State, respondentâ€™s fingerprint on the coffee cup lid tab establishes he was in the borrowed BMW on the same day the victim was last seen alive.Â  The fact that the BMW was found abandoned in Tennessee, the same state where respondent was located after his stay in Savannah, raises a suspicion of guilt[3] but is not evidence that respondent killed Dr. Cox.Â  Further, there is no evidence respondent was at the scene of the crime, which according to the Stateâ€™s theory was in Colleton County.Â  See State v. Martin, 340 S.C. 597, 533 S.E.2d 572 (2000); State v. Schrock, 283 S.C. 129, 322 S.E.2d 450 (1984) (directed verdict should have been granted where there was no substantial evidence establishing defendantâ€™s presence at scene of murder).Â  Accordingly, the Court of Appeals properly reversed the denial of a directed verdict of acquittal.
  AFFIRMED.
  WALLER AND PLEICONES, JJ., concur.Â  TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which BURNETT, J., concurs.
  
  CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In my view, the State presented sufficient evidence to warrant the trial judgeâ€™s denial of respondentâ€™s motion for a directed verdict of acquittal.Â Â  
  The events in this case occurred within a few days.Â  The victim was found dead on June 21 in Colleton County, off an access road that had rough terrain and overgrown brush.Â  The coroner estimated that the victim had been murdered on June 18.Â  Just days before the murder, on June 14-15, respondent and the victim met for the first time, in Savannah, and the two had sex.Â  Respondent was in town visiting Bobby Ray Ware, a truck driver who had a sexual relationship with the victim for over a year.Â  According to Ware, Respondent was carrying a gun.
  Ware left town for Chicago on the morning of June 17.Â  Respondent stayed behind at Wareâ€™s residence.Â  The next morning, June 18, the victim borrowed a nearly new BMW from one of his colleagues.Â  He withdrew $300 from an ATM in Hardeeville, near Colleton County.Â  Later, the victim was murdered by gunshot.Â  When his body was found, he was still wearing a watch and a gold ring, but his wallet and cash were missing.Â  
  On June 19, the very next day, respondent left Ware a phone message, asking Ware to call him in Tennessee.Â  On June 20, the BMW was found in Tennessee, near respondentâ€™s fatherâ€™s home.Â  The lead investigator reported that the exterior of the BMW had scratches on it, â€œlike it had been [driven] down something rough.â€Â  Respondentâ€™s thumbprint was found on a coffee cup lid left in the car.Â  
  Given the short timeframe within which these events occurred; the sexual relationship between the victim and respondent; the thumbprint evidence in the borrowed BMW; the scratches on the car; and the location of the abandoned car in Tennessee, near the place respondent was staying, there was enough evidence, in my view, from which respondentâ€™s guilt could be fairly and logically deduced.[4]Â  See State v. Mitchell, 341 S.C. 406, 409, 535 S.E.2d 126, 127 (2000) (the trial judge must submit the case to the jury if there is â€œany substantial evidence which reasonably tends to prove the guilt of the accused, or from which his guilt may be fairly and logically deducedâ€).
  Therefore, in my view, the court of appeals erred in reversing respondentâ€™s conviction.Â  
  BURNETT, J., concurs.


  [1]State v. Arnold, 351 S.C. 302, 569 S.E.2d 379 (Ct. App. 2002). 


  [2] Hardeeville is located along I-95 in Jasper County between Savannah and Colleton County. 


  [3]We note there is no evidence in the record establishing the distance between respondentâ€™s fatherâ€™s home and the site where the BMW was found.Â  Rand McNallyâ€™s Road Atlas indicates Gray, Tennessee, is about ten miles from Johnson City, Tennessee. 


  [4] It is also my view that had this case been submitted to the jury, respondent would have been entitled to the traditional circumstantial evidence charge as described in State v. Edwards, 298 S.C. 272, 379 S.E.2d 888, cert. denied, 493 U.S. 895 (1989).
