description: This order amends Rule 411(c)(1), SCACR, to raise the per claim maximum payout from $20,000 to $40,000 and the per lawyer maximum payout from $100,000 to $200,000.
text:
The Supreme Court of South Carolina
    In re: Amendments to Rule 411(c)(1), SCACR.
  
  O R D E R
  
  The Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection Committee of the South Carolina Bar has proposed amending Rule 411(c)(1), SCACR, to raise the per claim maximum payout from $20,000 to $40,000 and to raise the per lawyer maximum payout from $100,000 to $200,000.Â  The proposed amendments are approved.Â  
	 
  Pursuant to Article V, Â§ 4, of the South Carolina Constitution, we hereby amend Rule 411(c)(1), SCACR, to reflect the changes set forth above.Â Â  These amendments shall be effective immediately.Â  A copy of the amended rule is attached.
  IT IS SO ORDERED.
  
    
      
      
		s/Jean H. Toal                                      C.J.
		
                s/James E. Moore                                   J.
		
                s/John H. Waller, Jr.                                 J.
		
                s/E. C. Burnett, III                                      J.
		
                s/Costa M. Pleicones                              J.
    
  
  Columbia, South Carolina
  November 4, 2004
  
  AMENDMENTS TO RULE 411(c)(1)
  LAWYERS’ FUND FOR CLIENT PROTECTION
  (c) Duties of Lawyers' Fund for Client Protection Committee.
  
    (1) The Committee shall be authorized, commencing on January 1, 1980, to consider applications for reimbursement of losses which arise after the effective date of this Rule and which are caused by the dishonest conduct of a member of the South Carolina Bar who was acting either as a lawyer or in a fiduciary capacity customary to the practice of law in the matter in which the loss arose, but only to the extent to which these losses are not bonded or to the extent these losses are not otherwise covered; and provided the Bar member has died, has been adjudicated a bankrupt, has been adjudicated mentally incompetent, has been disbarred or suspended from the practice of law, has voluntarily resigned from the practice of law, has left the jurisdiction of this state or cannot be found, or has become a judgment debtor of the applicant based upon his dishonest conduct as a lawyer; or provided that the application has been certified to the Committee by the Commission on Lawyer Conduct of the Supreme Court or the Board of Governors of the South Carolina Bar as an appropriate case for consideration because the loss was caused by the dishonest conduct of a member of the South Carolina Bar.  For the purposes of this rule, dishonest conduct of a member of the South Carolina Bar shall include not only dishonest conduct committed by the member, but also dishonest conduct of any person who is not a member of the Bar employed by a member or the firm of a member to assist the member or firm in providing legal services.  Reimbursement for losses caused by dishonest conduct of an employee of a member or firm shall only be allowed if the acts giving rise to the loss occurred during the course of that employment.
    The Committee shall investigate applications which are brought to its attention.  The Committee shall be authorized and empowered to reject or allow applications in whole or in part to the extent that funds are available to it.  The Committee shall have complete discretion in determining the order, extent, and manner of payments of applications.  The payment to any applicant shall not exceed the sum of $40,000 per claim; provided, however, that the aggregate total of claims paid per attorney shall not exceed $200,000.  In operating the Lawyers' Fund for Client Protection pursuant to this Rule, the South Carolina Bar does not create or acknowledge any legal responsibility for the acts of individual lawyers in the practice of law.  All reimbursements of losses from the Lawyers' Fund for Client Protection shall be a matter of grace in the sole discretion of the Committee and not as a matter of right.  No client or member of the public shall have any right in the Lawyers' Fund for Client Protection as a third party beneficiary or otherwise.  No attorney shall be compensated for representing an applicant except as authorized by the Committee.
    In order for an application to be considered by the Committee, the application must be received by the South Carolina Bar within three (3) years of the date the applicant discovered or reasonably ought to have discovered the dishonest conduct.  No application may be considered after the expiration of six years from the date of the dishonest conduct.
    The Committee is further authorized to disburse funds as ordered by the Supreme Court pursuant to Rule 31(f) contained in Rule 413, SCACR.  Unless otherwise provided by the order of the Supreme Court, the Committee shall be entitled to reimbursement from the suspended, disbarred, disappeared, or deceased attorney or his estate.

title: State v. White
description: In this case, the Court concludes the defendant was entitled to a charge of ABHAN and was not entitled to a charge of simple assault and battery.  The Court also concluded the trial court properly admitted the testimony of an expert on post-traumatic stress disorder and treatment of sexual abuse.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        
The State, Petitioner/Respondent,
v.
Nickie White, Respondent/Petitioner.
        
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF 
  APPEALS

Appeal From Richland County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 25896
Heard October 7, 2004 - Filed November 
  15, 2004

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy AttorneyÂ  General John 
  W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, Assistant 
  Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin; and Solicitor Warren B. Giese, all of Columbia, 
  for Petitioner-Respondent.
Katherine Carruth Link, of West Columbia; and South Carolina Office of Appellate 
  Defense, both of Columbia, for Respondent-Petitioner.
        
      
    
  

 
  JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  This matter is before the Court on both partiesâ€™ petitions 
  for a writ of certiorari seeking review of the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision in 
  State v. White, 353 S.C. 566, 578 S.E.2d 728 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  We affirm 
  as modified.
FACTUAL 
  BACKGROUNDÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Following a jury trial, Respondent/Petitioner Nickie White (White) was convicted 
  of first-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC) and kidnapping.Â  White was sentenced 
  to consecutive prison terms of thirty years for the criminal sexual conduct 
  and ten years for kidnapping.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed Whiteâ€™s kidnapping 
  conviction, but reversed Whiteâ€™s first-degree CSC conviction, holding the circuit 
  court erred in refusing to charge assault and battery of a high and aggravated 
  nature (ABHAN) as a lesser-included offense of CSC.Â  The Court of Appeals also 
  concluded the trial court did not err in refusing to charge simple assault as 
  a lesser included offense of CSC and that any error in admitting the testimony 
  of the Stateâ€™s expert on post-traumatic stress disorder and sexual abuse was 
  harmless.Â  Id. at 575-76, 578 S.E.2d at 733.
The events giving rise to Whiteâ€™s conviction occurred in the early 
  morning hours of August 1, 1998, after White and the victim left a club in Columbia 
  where the victim was employed.Â  On several previous occasions, the victim and 
  White conversed while the victim worked.Â  On the night of July 31, 1998, White 
  was again a customer in the club.Â  White and the victim talked and danced.Â  
  When the victim needed to go for change during her shift, she asked White to 
  accompany her.Â  While the two were out, they took photographs together, kissed, 
  and held hands.Â  
White and the victim returned to the club and the victim accepted 
  Whiteâ€™s invitation to breakfast.Â Â  Soon thereafter, the victim testified she 
  became tired and frustrated because she had not made much money that night.Â  
  She therefore declined Whiteâ€™s breakfast invitation.Â  Despite her fatigue and 
  frustration, the victim agreed to drive White to his grandmotherâ€™s house where 
  he resided because he had no ride home.Â  When they arrived, White went inside 
  to check on his grandmother and then returned to the car where the victim was 
  waiting.Â  At this point, White and the victim offered very different accounts 
  of the events that followed.
The victim testified White asked her to take him to the store to buy a soda. 
  The victim further testified that White pulled a knife on her, held it to her 
  throat, and threatened to kill her if she did not do as he said.Â  White then 
  directed the victim to Earlewood Park where he ordered her to park the car.Â  
  When the victim attempted to escape, White ran her down and dragged her into 
  the woods.Â  White punched the victim, raped her, and took one of her rings.Â  
  White began choking the victim, and a struggle ensued for the knife. The victim 
  testified she retrieved the knife and began swinging it back and forth in Whiteâ€™s 
  direction, injuring White.Â  White then grabbed the victim and began choking 
  her again.Â  The victim threw the knife into the woods and grabbed Whiteâ€™s genitals.Â  
  The two continued to struggle and White suddenly walked off.Â  Shortly after 
  the attack, the victim encountered two men in the park who took her to the hospital.
Whiteâ€™s account differed.Â  According to White, after going to the 
  store for a soda, the victim asked him to go to Earlewood Park to watch the 
  sunrise.Â  White testified he brought along a butcher knife to protect the two 
  because the area has a history of drug-related violence.Â  Once White and the 
  victim arrived at the park, White stated the victim began â€œcoming onâ€ to him.Â  
  The victim began kissing him and the two engaged in what White contended was 
  consensual sex.Â  White testified he ended the sexual encounter because he began 
  thinking of his girlfriend.Â  According to White, the victim became so angry 
  that she grabbed Whiteâ€™s knife and stabbed him.Â  In self-defense, he hit her 
  in the eye.Â  
White testified he initially lied to law enforcement officers when 
  he said he had been robbed by five males dressed in camouflage because he was 
  scared and in shock.Â  
ISSUES

  
    
      
         I.  
         
  Did the Court of Appeals err in concluding White was entitled to an ABHAN charge?
      
      
         II.   
         
  Did the Court of Appeals err in affirming the trial courtâ€™s refusal to charge the jury on simple assault and battery
          as a lesser-included offense of first-degree CSC?
      
      
         III.     
         
  Did the Court of Appeals err in affirming the trial courtâ€™s admission of expert testimony on post-traumatic stress disorder and sexual 
  abuse?
      
    
  

      I.Â   

The State argues the Court of Appeals erred in holding White 
  was entitled to a charge on ABHAN as a lesser included offense of first-degree 
  CSC.Â  We disagree.
ABHAN is a lesser included offense of first degree CSC.Â  
  State v. Primus, 349 S.C. 576, 581, 564 S.E.2d 103, 106 (2002).Â  The 
  law to be charged is determined by the evidence presented at trial.Â  State 
  v. Todd, 290 S.C. 212, 349 S.E.2d 339 (1986).Â  A trial judge must charge 
  a lesser included offense if there is any evidence from which the jury could 
  infer the defendant committed the lesser rather than the greater offense.Â  Brightman 
  v. State, 336 S.C. 348, 350-351, 520 S.E.2d 614, 615 (1999).Â  Conversely, 
  a trial judge does not err by refusing to charge a lesser included offense where 
  there is no evidence tending to show the defendant was guilty only of the lesser 
  offense. State v. Funchess, 267 S.C. 427, 429, 229 S.E.2d 331, 332 (1976).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The Court of Appeals did not err in concluding the trial judge should have 
  charged the jury on ABHAN and reversing Whiteâ€™s CSC conviction.Â  State v. 
  Hill, 315 S.C. 260, 262, 433 S.E.2d 848, 849 (1993) (a trial court commits 
  reversible error if it fails to give a requested charge on an issue raised by 
  the evidence).Â  Both the victimâ€™s and Whiteâ€™s testimony support a charge of 
  ABHAN.Â  ABHAN is â€œan unlawful act of violent injury accompanied by circumstances 
  of aggravation.â€Â  Primus, 349 S.C. at 580, 564 S.E.2d at 105. â€œâ€˜Circumstances 
  of aggravationâ€™ is an element of ABHAN.â€Â  Id. â€œCircumstances of aggravation 
  include the use of a deadly weapon, the intent to commit a felony, infliction 
  of serious bodily injury, great disparity in the ages or physical conditions 
  of the parties, a difference in gender, the purposeful infliction of shame and 
  disgrace, taking indecent liberties or familiarities with a female, and resistance 
  to lawful authority.â€Â  Id. at 580-81, 564 S.E.2d at 105-106.Â Â  
The victimâ€™s testimony that prior to the commission of the CSC, White 
  dragged her into the woods while threatening her with the knife and punched 
  her in the eye supports a charge of ABHAN because it was contemporaneous with 
  the CSC.Â  Whiteâ€™s testimony that he and the victim engaged in consensual sex, 
  the victim stabbed him, and he hit the victim in the eye, is evidence from which 
  the jury could infer White committed ABHAN rather than CSC.Â  Cf. State 
  v. Fields, 356 S.C. 517, 589 S.E.2d 792 (Ct. App. 2003) (concluding the 
  defendant, in prosecution for CSC, was not entitled to jury instruction on ABHAN 
  where the defendant did not testify and there was no evidence presented at trial 
  to support the defenseâ€™s assertion that the sex was consensual).Â  In other words, 
  there was evidence from which the jury could have concluded the sex was consensual 
  and that the battery occurred after the sexual encounter.Â  Therefore, the Court 
  of Appeals did not err in holding White was entitled to an ABHAN charge and 
  reversing Whiteâ€™s first degree CSC charge.
II.
White argues 
  the Court of Appeals erred in affirming the trial courtâ€™s refusal to charge 
  simple assault and battery as a lesser included offense of first-degree criminal 
  sexual conduct.Â  We disagree, although we modify the Court of Appealsâ€™ analysis.
The Court of Appeals concluded this case is outside the 
  realm of simple assault and battery because the parties are of opposite sexes.Â  
  An example of a circumstance of aggravation includes difference in gender. Primus, 
  349 S.C. at 580, 564 S.E.2d at 105.Â Â  Simple assault and battery is an unlawful 
  act of violent injury to another, unaccompanied by any circumstances of aggravation.Â  
  State v. Tyndall, 336 S.C. 8, 21, 518 S.E.2d 278, 285 (Ct. App. 1999) 
  (emphasis added).Â  Therefore, the Court of Appeals determined that a simple 
  assault and battery charge was not proper because a circumstance of aggravation 
  existed in this factual scenario.
The Court of Appealsâ€™ holding appears to establish a bright 
  line rule that in all cases of assault and battery involving persons of different 
  genders, any assault must be one of a high and aggravated nature.Â  A difference 
  in gender, like any other aggravating circumstance, is a factor for the court 
  to consider in determining if the evidence warrants a jury charge on simple 
  assault.Â  A simple assault and battery may occur between a man and a woman, 
  depending on the degree of violence and the circumstances attending the attack. 
   [1] Â  See e.g., State 
  v. Young, 243 S.C. 187, 133 S.E.2d 210 (1963) (concluding that resistance 
  to lawful arrest, an aggravating factor, may warrant a charge on simple assault 
  and battery depending on the facts of the case).Â  Every assault and battery, 
  however slight, upon a member of the opposite sex does not become assault and 
  battery of a high and aggravated nature because of the very fact the attack 
  was upon one of the opposite sex. Â A difference in gender is a factor to be 
  considered, together with the other circumstances of the attack, in determining 
  the gravity of the assault and battery upon the person.
Although, a 
  difference in gender alone is not dispositive on whether the jury should be 
  charged with simple assault and battery, we believe under the facts of this 
  case, the trial judge properly denied Whiteâ€™s request for a simple assault and 
  battery charge.
III.
White contends 
  the Court of Appeals erred in concluding the trial court properly allowed Cole 
  Badger, a psychotherapist who counseled the victim and qualified as an expert 
  in post-traumatic stress disorder and assessment and treatment of sexual abuse, 
  to testify.Â  We disagree.
First, White argues Badgerâ€™s testimony in this case was 
  outside the scope of the exception for rape trauma evidence carved out by State 
  .v Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 859 (1993).Â  In Schumpert, 
  we held that both expert testimony and behavioral evidence are admissible as 
  rape trauma evidence to prove a sexual offense occurred where the probative 
  value of such evidence outweighs its prejudicial effect.Â  Id. at 506, 
  435 S.E.2d at 862.Â  White argues that Schumpert only applies in cases 
  in which there is a child victim.Â  Because the victim in the present case was 
  an adult when the incident occurred, Schumpert is inapplicable.Â  We disagree.Â  

Expert testimony on rape trauma may be more crucial in situations 
  where children are victims.Â  The inexperience and impressionability of children 
  often render them unable to effectively articulate the events giving rise to 
  criminal sexual behavior.Â  Nevertheless, the importance of rape trauma testimony 
  in the case of a child victim does not negate the relevance of rape trauma evidence 
  where the victim is an adult.Â  The purpose of rape trauma evidence is to prove 
  the elements of criminal sexual conduct since such evidence may make it more 
  or less probable the offense occurred.Â  State v. Alexander, 303 S.C. 
  377, 401 S.E.2d 146 (1991).Â  This is true whether the victim is an adult or 
  child.Â  See State v. Marks, 231 Kan. 645, 647 P.2d 1292 (1982) 
  (concluding in prosecution for rape in which defendant raised defense of consent, 
  psychiatristâ€™s testimony that twenty-one year old victim had been suffering 
  from rape trauma was relevant).Â  
Second, White argues the prejudicial effect of the expert 
  testimony outweighed its probative value.Â  Specifically, White argues Badger 
  should not have been allowed to testify the victimâ€™s symptoms were consistent 
  with those of a recent trauma sufferer.Â  We disagree.Â  Badgerâ€™s testimony is 
  consistent with the probative purpose of admitting rape trauma evidence, i.e., 
  to refute the defendantâ€™s contention that the sex was consensual and to prove 
  that a sexual offense occurred.Â  
Furthermore, we agree with the Court of Appeals that Badgerâ€™s 
  testimony was cumulative.Â  Even assuming the trial judge erred in admitting 
  the testimony, reversal is not warranted when evidence erroneously admitted 
  is merely cumulative.Â  See Rule 403, SCRE.Â  At trial Badger testified 
  that the victimâ€™s symptoms were consistent with someone who had suffered trauma 
  and had been raped. [2] Â  A nurse who examined the victim testified 
  that the victim was â€œupset and appeared frightened, disheveled; she was crying, 
  visible shaken.â€ Additionally, the nurse testified the victimâ€™s physical and 
  mental state was consistent with what the nurse was told happened to the victim.Â  
  Dr. Jenkins testified that the victim was â€œquite tearful; she was very agitatedâ€ 
  and that the victim had suffered trauma. 
Finally, White argues that Badger improperly testified she 
  believed the victim.Â  We conclude White opened the door to this testimony by 
  cross-examining Badger as to whether she had cases in which she did not believe 
  the alleged victim.Â  State v. Foster, 354 S.C. 614, 582 S.E.2d 426 (2003) 
  (one who opens the door to evidence cannot complain of its admission).Â  
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm as modified the Court 
  of Appealsâ€™ decision.
 AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

 
  [1] Â  See State v. Shea, 
    226 S.C. 501, 505-07, 85 S.E.2d 858, 859-60 (1995)Â  (trial court erred in 
    not charging jury on simple assault and battery where man was indicted for 
    assault with intent to ravish and assault and battery of high and aggravated 
    nature against female);Â  State v. Grace, 350 S.C. 19, 564 S.E.2d 331 
    (Ct. App. 2002), cert. denied, Nov. 21, 2002 (male defendant convicted 
    of three counts of simple assault and battery under indictments for criminal 
    sexual assault with his niece); State v. LaCoste, 347 S.C. 153, 553 
    S.E.2d 464 (Ct. App. 2001).

 
  [2] Â For example, Badger testified 
    that the victim had nightmares, could not concentrate, and was distrustful 
    of others.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Municipal Association of South Carolina,       
Plaintiff,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
AT&T Communications of the Southern States, Inc.,       
Defendant.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 25897
Heard October 5, 2004 - Filed November 
  22, 2004

CERTIFIED QUESTION ANSWERED


  
    
      
Robert Erving Stepp, Elizabeth Van Doren Gray, and
Robert E. Tyson, Jr.,Â  all of Sowell, Gray, Stepp 
  & Laffitte, L.L.C., of Columbia, for Plaintiff.
Belton Townsend Zeigler, of Columbia; and James 
  B. Richardson, Jr., of Richardson & Birdsong, of
Columbia, for Defendant 
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Pursuant 
  to Rule 228, SCACR, we accepted the following question on certification from 
  the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina: â€œDoes South 
  Carolina law allow municipalities to impose by ordinance a 5% per month penalty 
  for the late payment of business license taxes?â€Â  We hold South Carolina law 
  allows municipalities to impose such a penalty by ordinance.
BACKGROUND 
  FACTS [1] 
The plaintiff Municipal Association 
  of South Carolina (MASC)Â  is a non-profit organization composed of 229 municipalities 
  in South Carolina. [2] Â  In 1999, the General Assembly enacted the 
  South Carolina Telecommunications Act of 1999 (Act), codified at S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 58-9-2200, et. seq. (Supp. 2003).Â  Pursuant to this Act, municipalities can 
  impose a business license tax on telecommunications companies doing business 
  within a municipality.Â Â  Id.Â  The amount of the tax is based upon the 
  gross income from retail telecommunications services that either originate or 
  terminate within the municipality and is charged to a service address located 
  within the municipality.Â  Id.Â Â  Between 1999 and 2003, the business tax 
  was not to exceed 3/10 of one percent of the gross income for the preceding 
  year.Â Â  Id.Â  The tax is due January 1st and considered delinquent 
  if not paid by January 31st.Â  Most of the stateâ€™s municipalities 
  have authorized the MASC to collect the taxes from the telecommunications businesses 
  and the MASC is to receive 4% of what it collects.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

On March 2, 2000, defendant 
  AT&T Communications of Southern States, Inc., (AT&T) paid its telecommunications 
  business taxes for the year 1999 in the amount of $737,686.65.Â  On June 18, 
  2001, AT&T reported additional gross income for the tax year 1999 and paid 
  $1,025,937.65 in additional business license taxes. AT&T contends MASC refused 
  to accept this payment for nearly six (6) months. Â In any event, AT&T eventually 
  paid the additional taxes and now the MASC seeks a penalty of $872,047.00.Â  

Additionally, on February 28, 
  2002, AT&T paid its year 2001 taxes which were due on January 31, 2002.Â  
  The MASC is seeking a late payment penalty on the 2001 taxes in the amount of 
  $73,560.70 and requesting a statutory audit because the MASC contends that AT&T 
  actually owes more for 2001.Â  
DISCUSSION
This certified question revolves around the powers 
  granted to municipalities.Â  Section 5-7-30 lists the powers conferred upon municipalities.Â  
  Specifically, this section provides that a municipality:Â Â  

may enact regulations, resolutions, 
  and ordinances, not inconsistent with the Constitution and general law of this 
  State, including . . . levy a business license tax on gross income . . . . The 
  municipal governing body may fix fines and penalties for the violation of municipal 
  ordinances and regulations not exceeding five hundred dollars or imprisonment 
  not exceeding thirty days, or both.Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 5-7-30 (2004).Â  
  Additionally, â€œresponsibilities granted local government subdivisions by [the] 
  Constitution and by law shall include those fairly implied and not prohibited 
  by [the] Constitution.â€Â  S.C. Const. art. VIII, Â§ 17.Â  Furthermore, Â§ 5-7-10 
  states that "[t]he powers of a municipality shall be liberally construed 
  in favor of the municipality and the specific mention of particular powers shall 
  not be construed as limiting in any manner the general powers of such municipalities.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 5-7-10 (2004).

Determining if a local ordinance is valid is essentially a 
  two-step process. The first step is to ascertain whether the county or municipality 
  that enacted the ordinance had the power to do so.Â  If no such power existed, 
  the ordinance is invalid and the inquiry ends. However, if the local government 
  had the power to enact the ordinance, the next step is to ascertain whether 
  the ordinance is inconsistent with the Constitution or general law of this State. 
  . . . 

Hospitality Assâ€™n v. County of Charleston, 
  320 S.C. 219, 224, 464 S.E.2d 113, 116-7 (1995).
Clearly, the municipalities have the power to enact 
  these ordinances. See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 58-9-2200 et. seq.Â  The issue 
  is whether these ordinances are inconsistent with state law.Â  â€œ[I]n order for 
  there to be a conflict between a state statute and a municipal ordinance â€˜both 
  must contain either express or implied conditions which are inconsistent or 
  irreconcilable with each other. . . . If either is silent where the other speaks, 
  there can be no conflict between them.Â  Where no conflict exists, both laws 
  stand.â€™â€Â Â  The Town of Hilton Head v. Fine Liquors, 302 S.C. 550, 553, 
  397 S.E.2d 662, 664 (1990)(quoting McAbee v. Southern Ry. Co., 
  166 S.C. 166, 169-70, 164 S.E. 444, 445 (1932)).
Furthermore, the words of the 
  statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to 
  subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statute's operation.Â  Hitachi 
  Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992). 
  The language must also be read in a sense which â€œharmonizes with its subject 
  matter and accords with its general purpose.â€ Â Id. (citations 
  omitted).Â  
Section 5-7-30 specifically 
  provides for a $500 maximum fine and/or imprisonment for thirty (30) days for 
  a violation of a municipalityâ€™s ordinance.Â  The fine is not explicitly designated 
  as either civil or criminal. MASC contends the reference is to only a criminal 
  penalty and that the power to impose a civil penalty is implied.Â  AT&T contends 
  the $500 limit applies to both civil and criminal penalties.Â  
Giving the words of Â§ 5-7-30 
  their ordinary meaning and harmonizing the language with its subject matter, 
  we conclude the term â€œfineâ€ in 5-7-30 applies only to criminal fines.Â  By including 
  the reference to a maximum term of imprisonment, the General Assembly obviously 
  was contemplating a maximum criminal fine.Â  See 36A C.J.S. Fines Â§ 9 
  (2004)(â€œA statute providing that on a conviction the party guilty of violating 
  it shall be fined or imprisoned or both ordinarily contemplates a criminal proceeding 
  only.â€)Â  Furthermore, merely because a criminal remedy has been specifically 
  authorized does not mean the General Assembly meant this to be the exclusive 
  manner by which municipalities could enforce ordinances.Â  As noted above, the 
  powers of a municipality are to be liberally construed and include those fairly 
  implied and not prohibited by the Constitution.Â  S.C. Const. art. VIII, Â§ 17; 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 5-7-10. The power of the municipalities to impose a civil fine 
  for a violation of its ordinances is fairly implied and not prohibited.Â  Therefore, 
  in conclusion, we find these ordinances are not inconsistent with state law.Â  
  Accordingly, we answer the certified question affirmatively: South Carolina 
  law allows municipalities to impose by ordinance a 5% per month penalty for 
  the late payment of business license taxes.Â  
We also note that although the 
  issues of reasonableness and constitutionality of such a fine are apparently 
  at issue in this case, we are limited to answering only the certified question 
  before us.Â  Therefore, we specifically express no view as to the reasonableness 
  or constitutionality of the fine imposed.Â  
QUESTION ANSWERED.

    the district court's certification order. See Rule 228, SCACR.

 
   [2]  Apparently, almost every municipality in South 
    Carolina is a member.

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Susan M. Johnston, Deputy

R. Davis Howser, of Howser Newman & Besley, LLC, and Elizabeth Van Doren 
  Gray, of Sowell Gray Stepp & Laffitte, LLC, both of Columbia, for respondent.Â  

      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent 
  and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement 
  for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  
  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to a sixty (60) 
  day suspension from the practice of law.Â  See Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, 
  SCACR.Â  We accept the Agreement and definitely suspend respondent from the practice 
  of law in this state for a sixty (60) day period.Â  The facts, as set forth in 
  the Agreement, are as follows.Â  
FACTS
Respondent engaged in a business 
  relationship with South Carolina Real Estate Services, LLC, (RES), a company 
  managed by Cathy Pittman, daughter of Anna Knox (Knox), and Attorney Support, 
  Inc., (ASI), a company owned and managed by Knox.Â  These two companies provided 
  services to assist attorneys in the closing of real estate transactions.Â  
Neither Knox nor Pittman were employees 
  of respondent or his law firm during the period relevant to the Agreement.Â  
  Neither Knox nor Pittman have ever been admitted to the practice of law.Â  At 
  no time relevant to the facts in the Agreement were any persons employed by 
  ASI or RES licensed to practice law. Â Respondent had no interest in either ASI 
  or RES and paid them as independent contractors for their services on a case-by-case 
  basis.Â  
 The functions provided by RES and ASI included 
  communication with lenders, realtors, buyers and sellers, title abstract searches, 
  the preparation and review of legal documents for closings, attendance at closings, 
  issuance of title insurance, the receipt and disbursement of funds for the transaction, 
  and completion of follow up tasks, including but not limited to recording documents 
  in the public records.Â  In connection with the handling of the funds for real 
  estate closings for respondent, ASI provided an â€œescrow service.â€Â  All of these 
  functions took place at the offices of RES and/or ASI with the exception of 
  the actual closings which usually took place at respondentâ€™s office.Â  Almost 
  all U.S. mail, facsimiles, and other communications and deliveries related to 
  these functions were directed to the offices of RES and/or ASI, as were almost 
  all telephonic communications concerning real estate closings by respondent.Â  

In real estate closings, RES and/or ASI utilized computer 
  generated stationary with respondentâ€™s law office letterhead.Â  Use of respondentâ€™s 
  letterhead in this fashion was with respondentâ€™s knowledge and consent.Â  By 
  using respondentâ€™s letterhead and through other means which were known to respondent 
  and to which respondent consented, Knox represented herself as and caused others 
  to believe that she was an employee of respondent or respondentâ€™s law firm when, 
  in fact, she was not respondentâ€™s employee during the period relevant to the 
  Agreement.Â  
In completing the functions described above, neither 
  RES nor ASIâ€™s owners or employees were supervised by a licensed attorney.Â  Respondent 
  did not supervise the work of either RES or ASI, except to review the closing 
  documents and title abstract prior to closings.Â  Generally, all communications 
  concerning ASIâ€™s services were directly between respondent and Knox and any 
  services needed from RES were obtained by Knox.Â  Likewise, most communications 
  with lenders and parties to the real estate transactions were handled by Knox, 
  not respondent.Â  
Respondent caused or permitted all funds for these 
  real estate transactions assisted by RES and ASI to be deposited or wired into 
  the ASI â€œReal Estate Accountâ€ which was maintained by ASI at its office.Â  Respondent 
  directed funds being transferred by wire to be wired by lenders directly to 
  the ASI account managed by Knox at ASIâ€™s office.Â  When respondent received checks 
  made payable to his order or the order of his law firm, respondent endorsed 
  the checks and delivered them to Knox.Â  ASIâ€™s bank account was not an IOLTA 
  account and it was solely controlled by ASI owner and manager Knox.Â  Bank statements 
  and cancelled checks were sent directly to ASI.Â  Knox had exclusive signatory 
  authority over this bank account and controlled all aspects of it, including 
  deposits, disbursements, possession of checks and deposit slips, and the receipt 
  of monthly bank statements, cancelled checks, and other documents propagated 
  by the bank concerning account activity, all of which was maintained by and 
  in custody and control of Knox at ASIâ€™s office.Â  With the exception of a review 
  of the ledger accounts for each closing prepared by Knox, which respondent represents 
  he performed, respondent never inspected or audited the ASI account used by 
  Knox to deposit and thereafter disburse the proceeds of respondentâ€™s real estate 
  closings handled by ASI and RES. 
The arrangement between respondent and ASI (utilizing 
  the services of RES) was in effect for approximately four years.Â  Either during 
  or after each of the numerous transactions involving RES/ASI, respondent signed 
  the HUD-1 Settlement Statement attesting to the representation printed on the 
  Settlement Statement that respondent certified the funds itemized were an â€œaccurate 
  account of the funds which were received and have been or will be disbursed 
  by the undersigned . . .â€ (emphasis added) or words of similar import 
  or effect.Â  The term â€œundersignedâ€ on each of these HUD-1 Settlement Statements 
  refers to respondent.Â  In fact, respondent made no disbursements in connection 
  with the RES/ASI assisted real estate transactions and, instead, entrusted the 
  disbursements to be made by Knox from ASIâ€™s bank account, the checks and records 
  of which were maintained by Knox at ASIâ€™s office.Â  Respondent estimates he consummated 
  approximately 1051 real estate closings by using the services of ASI and/or 
  RES under the foregoing arrangement with Knox making disbursement of the proceeds 
  from the ASI bank account controlled by Knox.Â Â Â Â Â  
In or around February 2004, respondent learned from 
  Knoxâ€™s attorney that approximately twelve mortgage payoffs related to real estate 
  closings for respondentâ€™s clients handed by ASI and RES had not been paid.Â  
  Thereafter, respondent made inquiries to Knox about these open and unpaid mortgages 
  which should have been paid in full out of the proceeds of the closings.Â  When 
  confronted, Knox acknowledged to respondent that she had misappropriated funds 
  from the ASI account related to closings for respondentâ€™s clients.Â  Knox then 
  produced a document itemizing the transactions in which there were shortages 
  and the amounts thereof.Â  From the documentation submitted in support of the 
  Agreement, it appears the total amount of funds from respondentâ€™s clients misappropriated 
  by Knox was approximately $1,151,075.04.Â  These misappropriated monies were 
  funds that had been deposited in the ASI real estate account from closings ASI 
  handled for respondent.Â  These missing funds represent monies allocated for 
  payoffs of mortgages from twelve of respondentâ€™s clients.Â  Each of the HUD-1 
  Settlement Statements from the twelve closings from which money was appropriated 
  bears respondentâ€™s signature as â€œSettlement Agent.â€Â  One million one hundred 
  fifty one thousand seventy five dollars and four cents remains missing.Â  
After learning of Knoxâ€™s misappropriation, respondent 
  immediately filed a self-report with Disciplinary Counsel and with his errors 
  and omissions carrier and subsequently paid all amounts due on the mortgages.Â  
  Knox was indicted and subsequently pled guilty to the misappropriation of $1,151,075.04.Â  
  Knox admitted to perpetrating an ongoing scheme of retaining mortgage payoffs 
  from respondentâ€™s closings over a period of approximately four years.Â  It is 
  now known to respondent that Knox had been regularly misappropriating funds 
  from closings she handled for respondent and was replacing monies previously 
  misappropriated with monies from subsequent closings until her scheme became 
  known.Â  
Respondent did not at any time relevant to the foregoing 
  advise any of his clients of any limitations on his representation in connection 
  with real estate closings.Â  He did not advise his clients that unsupervised 
  non-lawyers were entrusted with the disbursement and accounting of all closing 
  funds, as well as the preparation and completion of closing documents and recording 
  of the same. 
Â Before Knoxâ€™s misappropriation scheme was discovered, 
  respondent became concerned about liability related to his arrangement with 
  Knox due to certain problems that arose with closings using ASI and/or RES services.Â  
  These problems were unrelated to and not indicative of Knoxâ€™s misappropriations.Â  
  Thereafter, respondent required Knox to present him with evidence of errors 
  and omission insurance policies related to the services being provided.Â  Respondent 
  now recognizes that ASI/RESâ€™ insurance policies covered only errors and omissions 
  and that the policies did not provide coverage for misappropriation. 
During the period of respondentâ€™s foregoing arrangement 
  with RES/ASI, respondent maintained the closing documents but did not maintain 
  the related disbursement records as required by Rule 417, SCACR.Â  Furthermore, 
  during this period, respondent failed to reconcile or even inspect ASIâ€™s bank 
  account used for deposits and disbursements of the funds of respondentâ€™s clients 
  as required by Rule 417, SCACR.Â  Additionally, respondent never inspected or 
  audited the â€œReal Estate Accountâ€ of ASI.Â  As a result, respondent failed to 
  safekeep the funds of his clients and others and, in so doing, assisted Knox 
  in the unauthorized practice of law. 
Â Respondent now recognizes that allowing non-employees 
  to have access to and control over money which belongs to clients and others 
  and was entrusted to respondent as a result of real estate closings constituted 
  misconduct regardless of whether there were shortages in the â€œescrow serviceâ€ 
  account provided by ASI.Â  Respondent now recognizes and acknowledges that the 
  use of an â€œescrow serviceâ€ as provided by Knox constitutes lawyer misconduct, 
  regardless of whether the funds were missing and whether the recordkeeping requirements 
  of Rule 417, SCACR, were conducted by respondent.Â  
To ODCâ€™s best knowledge and belief, respondent fully 
  cooperated with ODCâ€™s inquiries into this matter.Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that by his misconduct he has violated 
  the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  
  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to client); Rule 1.2(c) 
  (lawyer may limit objectives of representation with client consent after consultation); 
  Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep client reasonably informed about status of a matter); 
  Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall safeguard property of client; lawyer shall maintain 
  complete records of account funds); Rule 5.3 (lawyer shall make reasonable efforts 
  to ensure firm has in effect measures giving reasonable assurance conduct of 
  non-lawyer retained by lawyer is compatible with professional obligations of 
  lawyer; lawyer shall be responsible for conduct of non-lawyer retained by the 
  lawyer if that conduct would be a violation of the Rules of Professional Conduct 
  if engaged in by lawyer and lawyer ratifies the conduct); Rule 5.5(b) (lawyer 
  shall not assist a person who is not a member of the bar in the unauthorized 
  practice of law); Rule 8.4(a) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional 
  Conduct); Rule 8.4(d) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct involving dishonesty, 
  fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (lawyer shall not engage 
  in conduct that is prejudicial to administration of justice). Â In addition, 
  respondent admits he failed to comply with the recordkeeping provisions of Rule 
  417, SCACR.Â  Finally, respondent admits his misconduct constitutes a violation 
  of Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall 
  not violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction 
  regarding professional conduct of lawyers) and Rule 7(a)(5) (lawyer shall not 
  engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring 
  the courts or the legal profession into disrepute or conduct demonstrating an 
  unfitness to practice law).Â Â  
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and definitely 
  suspend respondent from the practice of law for a sixty (60) day period.Â  Within 
  fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit 
  with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 
  413, SCACR.
 DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  
  PLEICONES, J., not participating.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Edward Sloan, Jr., individually, and as a Citizen, Resident, Taxpayer 
        and Registered Elector of Greenville County, and on behalf of all others 
        similarly situated,        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Greenville County, a Political Subdivision of the State of South Carolina, 
        Dozier Brooks, Scott Case, C. Wade Cleveland, Bob Cook, Joseph Dill, Lottie 
        Gibson, Allen "Bunk" Johnson, Mark C. Kingsbury, Xanthene Norris, 
        Stephen Selby, and Dana Sullivan, Paul B. Wickensimer in their official 
        capacity as Greenville County Council Members,       
Petitioners.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF 
  APPEALS

Appeal From Greenville County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25899
Heard June 8, 2004 - Filed November 
  22, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Thomas H. Coker, Jr., Boyd B. Nicholson, Jr., and
Joel M. Bondurant, Jr., all of Haynsworth Sinker Boyd, PA, of Greenville, for 
  Petitioners.
James G. Carpenter and Jennifer J. Miller, both of The Carpenter Law Firm, 
  PC, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  We granted certiorari to consider a Court 
  of Appealsâ€™ decision reversing the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal as moot of two 
  suits brought by respondent (Sloan). [1] Â  Sloan v. Greenville County, Op. No. 
  2002-UP-598 (S.C. Ct. App. filed October 1, 2002).Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Sloan brought this action 
  against petitioners (collectively â€˜Countyâ€™) seeking a declaration that County 
  had violated its procurement ordinance in contracting a 1998 road construction 
  project and a 1999 family court renovation project.Â  The ordinance permits the 
  County to choose between several bidding methods when awarding these contracts, 
  and requires there be a written â€œdetermination for the method of source selection 
  utilized.â€Â  Sloan challenges the adequacy of the written determinations in these 
  two projects.Â  Both projects were completed before the suits were heard.
The circuit court dismissed 
  the road suit on the ground of mootness, rejecting Sloanâ€™s contention that the 
  â€œpublic importanceâ€ exception to mootness should be applied.Â  The family court 
  renovation suit was also dismissed as moot and the â€œpublic importanceâ€ argument 
  was similarly rejected.
The family court case 
  and the 1998 road case were heard together at the trial level and the orders 
  of dismissal were consolidated for appeal.Â  The Court of Appeals reversed the 
  orders dismissing the suits.Â  We granted Countyâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari.
ISSUE

Whether the Court of Appeals erred in reversing the circuit 
  courtâ€™s dismissal of Sloanâ€™s suits as moot?

ANALYSIS
This Court has recognized a â€œpublic importanceâ€ exception to mootness 
  holding that â€œan appellate court may decide questions of imperative and manifest 
  urgency to establish a rule for future conduct in matters of important public 
  interest.â€Â  Curtis v. State, 345 S.C. 557, 549 S.E.2d 591 (2001)(internal 
  citations omitted).Â  The determination whether a particular suit raises â€œquestions 
  of imperative and manifest urgencyâ€ must be decided on an individual basis.Â  
  In this case, the Court of Appeals focused not on the standard for invoking 
  this exception (â€œquestions of imperative and manifest urgencyâ€), but instead 
  on the label applied to it (â€œmatter of important public interestâ€).Â  In seeking 
  to define important public interest for purposes of applying this exception, 
  the Court of Appeals relied upon one of its decisions which held that, for purposes 
  of determining taxpayer standing, â€œthe expenditure of public funds pursuant 
  to a competitive bidding statute is of immense public importance.â€Â  Sloan 
  v. School Dist. Of Greenville County, 342 S.C. 515, 537 S.E.2d 299 (Ct. 
  App. 2000).Â  Relying upon this ruling, the court concluded â€œthe competitive 
  sealed bidding process is a question of public importance, both in the context 
  of standing and in the context of [Countyâ€™s compliance with the procurement 
  ordinanceâ€™s requirement] of the written determination.â€Â  Sloan v. Greenville 
  County, supra.
The Court of Appeals applied an incorrect standard, substituting â€œpublic importanceâ€ 
  for â€œimperative and manifest urgency.â€Â  Further, the court erred in adopting 
  a categorical exception to the mootness doctrine for cases questioning the competitive 
  sealed bidding process.Â  Such an approach is inconsistent with the limited nature 
  of the exception for questions of â€œimperative and manifest urgency.â€
Sloan would have the 
  courts declare whether written source selection determinations made by County 
  in awarding a 1998 road construction project and a 1999 family court renovation 
  project were adequate.Â  Assuming without deciding that Countyâ€™s compliance with 
  its procurement ordinance is an issue of public importance for purposes of invoking 
  this exception to the mootness doctrine, we must determine whether the questions 
  posed involve matters of â€œimperative and manifest urgency.â€ 
 Since these actions were commenced, the Court of Appeals has issued 
  two opinions addressing the adequacy of the Countyâ€™s written determinations 
  under the procurement ordinance. Â See Sloan v. Greenville County, 
  Op. No. 2004-UP-277 (S.C. Ct. App. filed April 22, 2004) (written determinations 
  used in 2001-2002 road projects); Sloan v. Greenville County, 356 S.C. 
  531, 590 S.E.2d 338 (2003) (2000 and 2001 road projects and 1999 forensics lab 
  renovation).Â  These two opinions provide County the judicial guidance in drafting 
  the determinations that Sloan is seeking in the present cases.Â  Further, the 
  County ordinance has been amended and now requires an independent monitor to 
  oversee the procurement of design-build services, and requires public notice 
  and an opportunity to be heard when the project cost exceeds $5 million.Â  In 
  light of these developments, we hold there is no imperative or manifest urgency 
  in obtaining an advisory opinion on the application of an obsolete procurement 
  ordinance to these completed projects. 
CONCLUSION
The Court of Appealsâ€™ 
  opinion, which reversed the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of these suits as moot, 
  is 
REVERSED.
 WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  MOORE, J., dissenting in a separate 
  opinion in which TOAL, C.J., concurs.



 
JUSTICE MOORE (dissenting):Â  I respectfully dissent from the majority 
  opinion because I believe the Court of Appeals properly reversed the circuit 
  courtâ€™s dismissal of two suits brought by respondent (Sloan).Â  I would affirm 
  as modified the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion and find that Sloanâ€™s suits are not 
  moot and that Sloan has standing to bring the suits in circuit court.
Mootness
 An appellate court will not pass on moot and academic questions or 
  make an adjudication where there remains no actual controversy.Â  Curtis v. 
  State, 345 S.C. 557, 549 S.E.2d 591 (2001), cert. denied, 535 U.S. 
  926 (2002).Â  Moot appeals differ from unripe appeals in that moot appeals result 
  when intervening events render a case nonjusticiable.Â  Id.Â  A case becomes 
  moot when judgment, if rendered, will have no practical legal effect upon the 
  existing controversy.Â  Id.Â  This is true when some event occurs making 
  it impossible for the reviewing Court to grant effectual relief.Â  Id.
An exception to the mootness doctrine is that questions of public 
  interest originally encompassed in an action should be decided for future guidance, 
  however abstract or moot they may have become in the immediate contest.Â  Ashmore 
  v. Greater Greenville Sewer Dist., 211 S.C. 77, 44 S.E.2d 88 (1947).Â  The 
  Court of Appeals found, pursuant to Ashmore, that this case falls into 
  the public importance exception to the mootness doctrine and that a ruling on 
  the merits of Sloanâ€™s suits would provide future guidance to petitioner.
The majority, relying on Curtis v. State, supra, finds 
  the Court of Appeals applied the incorrect standard for determining whether 
  a case falls into the public importance exception to the mootness doctrine.Â  
  The majority states â€œthe Court of Appeals focused not on the standard for invoking 
  this exception (â€œquestions of imperative and manifest urgencyâ€), but instead 
  on the label applied to it (â€œmatter of important public interestâ€).â€
This Court, in Curtis, stated that one exception to the mootness 
  doctrine is that:Â  â€œan appellate court may decide questions of imperative 
  and manifest urgency to establish a rule for future conduct in matters 
  of important public interest.â€Â  Curtis, 345 S.C. at 568, 549 S.E.2d 
  at 596 (emphasis added).Â  However, I do not believe Curtis, via the language 
  italicized above, imposed an additional requirement to the public importance 
  exception to the mootness doctrine.Â  To read Curtis to impose a requirement 
  that a question must be of â€œimperative and manifest urgencyâ€ to meet the public 
  importance exception is against the jurisprudence of this state.Â  See 
  Berry v. Zahler, 220 S.C. 86, 66 S.E.2d 459 (1951) (questions of public 
  interest should be decided for future guidance, however abstract or moot they 
  may have become in the immediate contest); Ashmore v. Greater Greenville 
  Dist., supra (same).Â  I would hold that questions of public interest 
  should be decided for future guidance without a requirement that there be some 
  urgency to the matter. 
Accordingly, the Court of Appeals correctly held that this case falls squarely 
  within the public interest exception.Â  As the Court of Appeals has noted in 
  a similar case, an important public interest exists in the stewardship of public 
  funds and a strong need exists to provide guidance for future procurement decisions.Â  
  Sloan v. Greenville County, 356 S.C. 531, 590 S.E.2d 338 (Ct. App. 2003) 
  (Sloan 2003).Â  The inability to provide any effective relief in a case 
  should not be a barrier to the courtâ€™s consideration of a question of exceptional 
  public interest.Â  Id.
Because a question of important public interest is involved, I would 
  hold the Court of Appeals properly reversed the circuit courtâ€™s decision to 
  dismiss the suits as moot.
Standing
Although the Court of Appeals did not address the issue whether Sloan 
  had standing to bring the suits against petitioners, I would now address this 
  issue.Â  
To have standing to institute an action, one must have a personal stake in 
  the subject matter of the lawsuit.Â  Evins v. Richland County Historic Pres. 
  Commâ€™n, 341 S.C. 15, 532 S.E.2d 876 (2000).Â  This Court has consistently 
  held that a private individual may not invoke the judicial power to determine 
  the validity of an executive or legislative act unless the private individual 
  can show that, as a result of that action, a direct injury has been sustained, 
  or that there is immediate danger a direct injury will be sustained.Â  Joytime 
  Distribs. & Amusement Co., Inc. v. State, 338 S.C. 634, 528 S.E.2d 647 
  (1999), cert. denied, 529 U.S. 1087 (2000).Â  Moreover, the injury must 
  be of a personal nature to the party bringing the action, not merely of a general 
  nature that is common to all members of the public.Â  Id.Â  
 The general rule is that a taxpayer may not maintain a suit to enjoin 
  the action of State officers when he has no special interest and his only standing 
  is the exceedingly small interest of a general taxpayer.Â  Crews v. Beattie, 
  197 S.C. 32, 14 S.E.2d 351 (1941).Â  The mere fact that the issue is one of public 
  importance does not confer upon any citizen or taxpayer the right to invoke 
  a judicial determination of the issue.Â  Id.Â  For a plaintiff to have 
  taxpayer standing, the party must demonstrate some overriding public purpose 
  or concern to confer standing to sue on behalf of his fellow taxpayers.Â  Sloan 
  v. Greenville County, 356 S.C. 531, 590 S.E.2d 338 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  See 
  also Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 511 S.E.2d 69 (1999) 
  (standing may be conferred upon a party when an issue is of such public importance 
  as to require its resolution for future guidance).
Sloan has standing because the question presented is of such substantial 
  public importance as to warrant a resolution for future guidance.Â  See, 
  e.g. Sloan v. School Dist. Of Greenville County, 342 S.C. 515, 
  537 S.E.2d 299 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The public interest involved is the prevention 
  of the unlawful expenditure of money raised by taxation.Â  
With specific regard to procurement of services for public works projects, 
  the Court of Appeals has found:

The expenditure of public funds pursuant to a competitive bidding statute is 
  of immense public importance.Â  Requiring that contracts only be awarded through 
  the process of competitive sealed bidding demonstrates the lengths to which 
  our government believes it should go to maintain the publicâ€™s trust and confidence 
  in governmental management of public funds.Â  The integrity of the competitive 
  sealed bidding process is so important that in some states â€œonce a contract 
  is proved to have been awarded without the required competitive bidding, a waste 
  of public funds [is] presumed ... without showing that the municipality suffered 
  any alleged injury.â€

Sloan 2003, 356 S.C. at 550-551, 590 S.E.2d at 348-349 (citation and 
  quotation omitted).
The Court of Appealsâ€™ reasoning in Sloan 2000 and Sloan 
  2003 compels the same result in the instant case.Â  Here, Sloan has an interest 
  as a taxpayer in how public funds were spent.Â  The projects required the expenditure 
  of millions of taxpayer dollars and this burden was borne exclusively by the 
  taxpaying citizens of Greenville County.Â  Sloan, therefore, has a material interest 
  in whether the County followed the procurement procedures set out in the county 
  code.
As stated in Sloan 2003, the issue in the present case is 
  of sufficient public importance to confer standing.Â  Resolution of the issues 
  in this case will likely have an impact on government practices beyond the confines 
  of the case itself.Â  Greenville County and other public entities must be accountable 
  under the laws that govern how they spend public money.
For these reasons, Sloan has standing to pursue these suits in the 
  circuit court.Â  Therefore, I would affirm as modified the opinion of the Court 
  of Appeals.
TOAL, C.J., concurs.

 
   [1]  The cases were combined for purposes of this appeal.

In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Allendale County Sheriffâ€™s Office,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

and

  
    
      
South Carolina Law Enforcement Division,       
Intervenor,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Two Chess Challenge II, games of skill,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Allendale County
Perry M. Buckner, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25900
Heard November 3, 2004 - Filed November 
  22, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Robert D. Cook, 
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General C. Havird Jones, Jr., all of Columbia, 
  for Appellant and Intervenor.
Richard Mark Gergel and W. Allen Nickles, III, both of Gergel, 
  Nickles & Solomon, of Columbia, for Intervenor.
A. Camden Lewis and Ariail E. King, both of Lewis Babcock 
  & Hawkins, of Columbia; H. Woodrow Gooding, of Gooding & Gooding, of 
  Allendale; and Jonathan Scott Altman, of Derfner, Altman & Wilborn, of Charleston, 
  for Respondents.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  The 
  magistrate court ruled, and the circuit court affirmed, that the two Chess Challenge 
  II machines examined, and all machines operating in a similar manner, are games 
  of skill that are lawful to possess.Â  After certifying this appeal for review 
  pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, we reverse in part and affirm in part.
Factual/Procedural 
  Background
On September 23, 2003, the Allendale County Sheriffâ€™s 
  Office (Sheriffâ€™s Office) received an anonymous phone call that video poker 
  machines were being placed in Bertâ€™s Fast Stop, a convenience store in Fairfax, 
  South Carolina.Â  Two machines were found and taken to the magistrateâ€™s office 
  for a ruling as to their legality.
The machines contained the game Chess Challenge 
  II, a coin-operated game that has a payout feature.Â  The game has four rotating 
  reels in which seven icons spin according to a fixed sequence.Â  Seven different 
  icons (pawn, shield, horse, castle, prince, queen, and king) appear in various 
  combinations over the course of a fixed 255-icon sequence and then repeat.Â  
  The player is able to stop each reel individually by pushing the corresponding 
  button.Â  To win, a player must match icons on three of the four reels.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

After examining the machines, hearing oral argument, considering 
  expert reports, play trials, and affidavits, 
  [1]  the magistrate ruled the following: 

[t]he Chess Challenge II games examined and all those 
  operating in an identical manner are games of skill that are lawful 
  to possess, own and operate under South Carolina law as redemption machines 
  distributing prizes, including gift certificates, and merchandise. 

(emphases added).Â  
In addition, the magistrate found that the developer of Chess 
  Challenge II had â€œtaken certain measures to insure that all Chess Challenge 
  II games operate in the identical manner as those examined,â€ which would allow 
  â€œlaw enforcement to quickly detect whether any effort [had] been made to alter 
  the operational characteristicsâ€ of the game. 
After the ruling, the solicitor filed a notice 
  of appeal on behalf of the Sheriffâ€™s Office.Â  But at the beginning of the hearing, 
  the solicitor asked the judge to deny the appeal:

  
  
    
      Solicitor:
       Your Honor please, I have reviewed the order of 
  [the magistrate].Â  I have reviewed the information that was presented during 
  that hearing.Â  I have reviewed the machine and I have listened to the advice 
  of someone in whom I have great confidence and faith, and I withdraw my appeal.Â  
  Donâ€™t withdraw my appeal, sir, I think you should deny my appeal.
        
    
    
      The Court:
       So you think I should affirm the judgment of Judge 
  Love?
        
    
    
      Solicitor: 
       Yes, sir.
    
  
  

 Based on the solicitorâ€™s request, and without further consideration, 
  the circuit judge affirmed the magistrateâ€™s order.
 Four days later, the solicitor inexplicably filed 
  a motion for reconsideration on the basis that the magistrate did not have the 
  authority to find that the machines examined and all those operating in an identical 
  manner were lawful.Â  The motion was denied.
Soon after, the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division (SLED) 
  filed a motion for relief from the order and an alternative motion to alter, 
  amend or reconsider, arguing that jurisdiction was proper only as to the two 
  machines before the court, not as to machines operating in an identical manner 
  throughout the state.Â  Moreover, SLED argued that because it was not served 
  with notice or given an opportunity to be heard, it was not bound by the courtâ€™s 
  order.
SLED subsequently withdrew its motion for relief, and moved, 
  instead, to intervene and to have the case certified to this Court.Â  Both motions 
  were granted.
The Sheriffâ€™s Office and SLED have raised the following issues 
  for review:

  I.       Did the lower courts 
  have jurisdiction to rule on the legality of Chess Challenge II machines not 
  before the court?
  II.    Is the magistrateâ€™s order void for 
  lack of controversy and lack of notice to SLED? 

Law/Analysis
Standard of Review
When there is any evidence, however slight, tending 
  to prove the issues involved, this Court may not question a magistrate courtâ€™s 
  findings of fact that were approved by a circuit court on appeal.Â  State 
  v. 192 Coin-Operated Video Game Machines, 338 S.C. 176, 185, 525 S.E.2d 
  872, 876 (2000).Â  An action for forfeiture of property is a civil action at 
  law.Â  Id.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Lack of 
  Jurisdiction
The Sheriffâ€™s Office and SLED contend that the magistrate 
  lacked jurisdiction to determine the legality of machines that were not before 
  the court.Â  We agree.
South Carolina statutory law prescribes the procedure for 
  seizing and destroying unlawful machines:

[a]ny machine, board, or other device prohibited by Section 
  12-21-2710 [2]  must be seized by any law enforcement 
  officer and at once taken before any magistrate of the county in which the machine, 
  board, or device is seized who shall immediately examine it, and if satisfied 
  that it is in violation of Section 12-21-2710 or any other law of this State, 
  direct that it be immediately destroyed.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-21-2712 (2000).
In general, it is within the Stateâ€™s police power to take 
  gaming devices by forfeiture.Â  Westside Quik Shop, Inc. v. Stewart, 341 
  S.C. 297, 303, 534 S.E.2d 270, 273 (2000).Â  An action for forfeiture is a civil 
  in rem action at law that is, by its nature, a penal action that must 
  be strictly construed.Â  Pope v. Gordon, 359 S.C. 572, 581, 598 S.E.2d 
  288, 293 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Consequently, in rem forfeiture statutes must 
  be interpreted in light of the evil sought to be remedied and in a manner that 
  is consistent with the statuteâ€™s purpose.Â  Id. (quoting Ducworth v. 
  Neely, 319 S.C. 158, 162, 459 S.E.2d 896, 899 (Ct. App. 1995)).Â  
The facts in a prior decision by this Court demonstrate that 
  the seizure and destruction process outlined in section 12-21-2712 must be followed 
  even when the machines seized have been previously deemed illegal.Â  In 192 
  Coin-Operated Video Game Machines, SLED seized 192 â€œCherry Masterâ€ and â€œ8-Linerâ€ 
  video machines.Â  Id. at 183, 525 S.E.2d at 876.Â  These machines had previously 
  been deemed illegal gambling devices by this Court. See State v. One Coin-Operated 
  Video Game Machine, 321 S.C. 176, 467 S.E.2d 443 (1996) (finding â€œCherry 
  Masterâ€ is an illegal slot machine); State v. Four Video Slot Machines, 
  317 S.C. 397, 453 S.E.2d 896 (1995) (finding â€œLucky 8 Lineâ€ is an illegal slot 
  machine).Â  Although the machines had previously been deemed illegal, the seizure 
  and forfeiture process outlined in section 12-21-2712 was still followed: SLED 
  obtained a search warrant and seized the 192 machines; and the magistrate personally 
  examined the machines, determined that they were illegal, and ordered their 
  destruction. 192 Coin-Operated, 338 S.C. at 183, 525 S.E.2d at 875.Â  

Also while at the warehouse, SLED discovered an additional 
  23 machines that it believed were illegal.Â  Once again, SLED obtained a search 
  warrant and seized the machines; a magistrate examined them, found them to be 
  illegal, and ordered their destruction.Â  Id.Â  This Court affirmed both 
  destruction orders. Id. at 202, 525 S.E.2d at 886.Â  
In the present case, the magistrate ruled on the legality 
  of the two machines before the court and â€œall those [machines] operating in 
  an identical manner.â€Â  This broad ruling exceeded the scope of the magistrateâ€™s 
  authority and is contrary to the machine-by-machine forfeiture process outlined 
  in the statute and carried out in other cases.Â  Therefore, we find that the 
  magistrate court lacked jurisdiction to determine the legality of machines not 
  before court.Â Â 
As to the two machines seized, examined, and deemed legal, 
  there is nothing preventing the Sheriffâ€™s Office or other law enforcement officials 
  from seizing the machines once again for the magistrateâ€™s examination. Because 
  video machines may be manipulated so as to change their nature from lawful to 
  unlawful, law enforcement may, based on probable cause, seize the machines in 
  question once again.Â  In other words, the effect of the magistrateâ€™s order is 
  that it deems the machines lawful at the time they were seized and examined.Â  

II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Other 
  Grounds
The Sheriffâ€™s Office and SLED argue that the magistrateâ€™s 
  ruling is void because (1) an actual controversy did not exist, and (2) SLED 
  was not notified of the proceedings.Â  We disagree with both arguments.Â  
First, in support of their argument that the magistrateâ€™s 
  ruling is void for lack of controversy, the Sheriffâ€™s Office and SLED claim 
  that they were not given the opportunity to present evidence that the machines 
  were illegal.Â  While it is true that the magistrateâ€™s order only cites evidence 
  presented by Respondents, there is no evidence in the record suggesting that 
  the Sheriff or other law enforcement officials did not have an opportunity to 
  present evidence that the machines were illegal.Â  
Second, a plain reading of the statute does not support the 
  argument that the magistrateâ€™s order should be voided because SLED was not notified 
  of the forfeiture hearing.Â  See State v. Blackmon, 304 S.C. 270, 
  403 S.E.2d 660 (1991) (a statute must be given its plain and ordinary meaning).Â  
  The statute states that the machines may be â€œseized by any law enforcement officer.â€Â  
  Nothing in the statute specifically provides that SLED must be notified before 
  the magistrate makes a determination.Â  
Therefore, the magistrateâ€™s order should not be voided for 
  lack of controversy or lack of notice to SLED.
Conclusion
We affirm the magistrateâ€™s decision finding that 
  the two Chess Challenge II machines seized and examined were lawful.Â  Because 
  the magistrate did not have the authority to deem â€œall those [machines] operating 
  in an identical mannerâ€ lawful, we reverse that portion of the ruling. 
 MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT, JJ., and Acting Justice 
  G. Thomas Cooper, concur.

 
   
    [1]  An affidavit by Solicitor Ralph Hoisington was submitted in which 
    he stated the following: â€œit is my belief that the Chess Challenge II game 
    operates in a different manner from the illegal games of chance that have 
    appeared in the state of South Carolina. Chess Challenge II operates utilizing 
    a repeating pattern and does not utilize features that would prevent a playerâ€™s 
    skill from determining the outcome of the game.Â  In addition, a player is 
    able to identify the icons as they appear, and to time the stopping of the 
    game to increase the chance of winning.â€Â  

 
   
    [2]  This section provides, in part, the following:Â  [i]t is unlawful 
    for any person to keep on his premises or operate â€¦ any vending or slot machine, 
    punch board, pull board, or other device pertaining to games of chance â€¦ including 
    those â€¦ that display different pictures, words, or symbols, at different plays 
    or numbers, whether in words or figures or, which deposit tokens or coins 
    at regular intervals or in varying numbers to the player or in the machine 
    â€¦.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-21-2710 (2000).
